The overall aim of this project is to improve access to and quality delivery of education and Sexual Reproductive Health via Social Accountability. The purpose is to increase the number of adolescent girls enrolling and completing education as well as girls involved in decision making processes in the community and school management. The project also intends to change the attitudes and behaviour of girlsand parentsand communities and officials in relation to adolescent girls  right to educationand gender and sexual reproductive health .

The overarching goal of the project is gender equality and the realisation of girls  rights in Cambodia. The project purpose is to increase the number of adolescent girls completing Lower Secondary education by addressing some of the key economicand socialand culturaland and political barriers. The project will directly benefit approximately 3000 adolescent girls from 26 Secondary schools across six Districts in Cambodia.

Plan International is implementing a 6-month project to support the ongoing effort to combat Ebola transmission in Guinea through intensified social mobilization and improved contact tracing in four Regions, covering the cities of Conakry, Nzerekore, Gueckedou, Macenta, Yomou, Kissidougou, Coyah, Forecariah, Dubreka, and Telimele.  Reaching a total of over one million Guineans in ten key prefectures through increased inter-personal and media messaging and improved contact tracing, the project will support the Government of Guinea’s ongoing effort to break the cycle of Ebola transmission and prevent new infections.

The overall goal of the project is to decrease maternal, perinatal and neonatal (newborn) mortality in Nepal. The objective of the project is to improve access to and utilization of community-based maternal and childhealth services by disadvantaged pregnant women through Pregnant Women’s Groups. The project will form 3,300 PWGs, reaching 394,080 direct beneficiaries (mothers and newborns) and732,600 indirect beneficiaries.

In Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH), persons with mental health disorders have access to a limited scope of care and are frequently socially excluded and discriminated. The project supports the reform of mental health care services in BiH. It aims to reduce stigmatization, enhance social inclusion and improve quality of life of people with mental disorders, their families, and those at risk of developing mental health problems. This will lead to an improvement of a general well-being of these persons in a long run.

The quality of care is dependent on the proper functioning system of infections control in hospitals which should guarantee that patients are not infected inside the hospitals during their treatment. Therefore it is essential to apply infection control measures in hospitals (hand hygiene, appropriate sterilization, rational use of antibiotics..) and to establish monitoring system to ensure adherence. In this context, Swiss Cooperation has developed, in partnership with the Swiss Red Cross, a simple but efficient Infection Control model. The model has been piloted successfully in 16 health facilities in 2 oblasts under the Health Care Waste Management project. The exit phase of the project will allow the introduction of the infection control model into all remaining 234 health facilities and its institutionalization into the national health system.

The project will contribute to poverty reduction through improved maternal and adolescent health in Uganda. This will be done through building capacity of the health system to provide high quality adolescent friendly services&SRHR services to the community and increasing demand for these services at community level. The project will reach 745,020 people. These include girls and women of reproductive age (15-49 years) and adolescents and young people (girls and boys aged 10-24 years).

?This grant will be used to implement a post-drought malaria threat assessment program in partnership with Ethiopia?s Federal Ministry of Health, Ethiopia?s National Malaria Control Program, and Fio Corporation. In particular, it will address management and surveillance of malaria. Successful malaria control and elimination programs require quality data on adherence to NMCP case management guidelines and accurate and timely reporting of all suspected malaria cases. The Ministry of Health has recognized and is requesting for a surveillance system that can provide accurate data from the regions, critical for outbreak management. The project would place 80 Deki Readers enabled with the Fionet software, on a year subscription modality, to a total of 80 health posts across the selected woredas/districts. The system will be used to test, treat and track cases of malaria in the post-drought setting in Ethiopia. The principal results the investment would achieve are real-time, quality controlled, accurate data flowing from point of care in remote locations on diagnostics, treatment, protocol adherence and consumables for all suspected cases of malaria. To achieve this effect, the project will take on training of master trainers on the Fionet system, supportive supervision, and training of community level providers. The project will also communicate to Ministry of Health to address accurate and timely data needs in order to manage resources and programs and inform health policy.

Phase II will build on the successes of Phase I, while also taking into consideration the changing national context, lessons learned from the first phase, PSI's growing regional experience in developing financially sustainable social franchises, and the rapidly evolving mobile technology landscape to deliver an evidence-based, gender transformative programme that creates synergies with other programming and leaves in place lasting solutions?. Phase II will employ a four-pronged approach: (1) evidence-based social and behaviour change communications (SBCC), (2) delivery of high-quality SRH services, (3) distribution of a wide range of contraceptive methods, and (4) community engagement to break down the systematic barriers individuals face to accessing these SRH products and services. The four prongs of this approach will be seamlessly linked through the expanded use of Triggerise?s mobile phone-based technology platform Movercado, enabling individuals reached by SBCC to more readily access and use the SRH products and services available to them and enabling PSI/Burundi to more rapidly collect and analyse information for a data-driven, audience-centred response. In support of Burundi?s FP acceleration plan, Phase II will see the expansion of the Tunza franchise to 60 clinics across nine provinces. PSI/Burundi will launch an emergency contraceptive pill in all Tunza clinics, and post-abortion care services will be expanded from nine to 19 clinics. Social marketing activities will similarly expand, with the launch of Confiance oral contraceptives in pharmacies across the country and a revised sales and distribution strategy that will enable greater cost recovery.

SFH South Africa/PSI are a sub to TB HIV Care under an award for HTS . The goal of the program is to scale-up and strengthen the delivery of quality HIV and TB/HIV prevention services with facility and community sites.

?The goal/purpose of the USAID Transform Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Activity is to reduce preventable deaths and illness in Ethiopia due to diarrheal disease, particularly among children under five. Through development and testing of scalable and replicable market-based models, the Transform WASH Activity will support the Government of Ethiopia (GOE) and the One WASH National Program (OWNP) to increase use of improved WASH products and services. PSI/Ethiopia will lead a team comprised of IRC Wash, Plan USA, and SNV from January 1, 2017 ? December 31, 2021.

?The goal of JeuneS3 in Benin is to contribute to the reduction of socio-cultural and cultural barriers that promote gender norms on the sexual and reproductive health rights of young people to achieve SDGs 3, 4, 5 and 16 through creation of a sociocultural and religious environment conducive to respect for equity, gender in health and the use of sexual and reproductive health services by young people.
?ASF is holding a training for youth-friendly service providers in DRC.

Partnering with UNICEF to implement social marketing of WaterGuard household water streatment in ten urban slum communities in Monrovia and 4 rural districts, and sanitation marketingin one community in Monrovia. With gender integration in mind, project will increase equitable access to water and sanitation services.

The purpose of this project are to reduce HIV incidence and transmission and to reduce HIV-related morbidity and mortality in Lesotho, which will be achieved through  short-term and intermediate outcomes. The priority target population are adult men aged 20-49, discordant couples/partners and key populations.

?The Integrated HIV/AIDS Project (IHAP) in DRC delivers HIV treatment and prevention services to the Congolese people in Kinshasa. PSI is a subaward to the Elizabeth Glaser Pediactric AIDS Foundations (EGPAF) under this grant and will be working in interpersonal communication efforts to get people in treatment and continue follow up with those already in treatment.

Goal 2: Grow the market for LARCs as an important option for adolescents in Honduras through training and support of 10 providers, including quality assurance, and providing the Secretariat of Health (SOH) an initial trial stock.
Consultancy services for the implementation of SBCC activities to promote LLIN use in Tanzania mainland

PACE Uganda is a Sub to Mildmay on a HIV related project funded by CDC. PACE will lead the implementation of the community component in 7 districts of Mubende.? This will include scale up of HIV counselling and testing, HIV prevention and improved linkage of care and treatment services.

?The study will contribute to the constitution of a database and information on the menstruation of young girls as well as the perceptions and beliefs around this subject. Obtaining these data will help better align future UNICEF interventions to reduce the loss of girls' school days due to menstruation. It will take place in 4 sites Anosy, Androy, Atsimo Atsinanana and Analanjirofo.?

This project will evaluate existing pilots of 99DOTS in Yangon, collaboratively build training materials and protocols for the best practices, and expand the program to future sites. The ultimate goal is to have a well-understood, highly-functioning demonstration of 99DOTS and the Sun Quality Health netowrk as a demonstration to both internal and external stakeholders of the benefits of further expansion and investment.

A collaborative project to incubate sustainable, scalable, hypertension treatment models in low-middle income patient populations in low-middle income countries through understanding patients, products and providers in Vietnam and Myanmar.

This project forms part of CIFF?s Accelerating Children?s Treatment (ACT) investment. HIV self-tests are a new technology that enable a person to test themselves for HIV in private. Using HIV self-testing to increase the number of adolescents tested for HIV and on treatment is aligned with the ACT objectives, and fits with CIFF?s wider adolescent sexual health goals. This project aims to demonstrate the potential of the private sector to distribute oral and blood-based HIV self-testing, as a route to early HIV diagnosis and treatment. Working in two counties (Nairobi and Mombasa) in Kenya, PSI will design models to distribute HIV self-tests through pharmacy chains and small, franchised clinics that see a high number of young clients. The investment will prime the market for wider roll-out by strengthening policy support for HIV self-testing in the private sector, build demand among adolescents and young adults, and demonstrate uptake, making sure those testing positive are linked to HIV treatment, while those testing negative are supported to stay that way. Through this investment 82,000 self-tests will be distributed of which it is projected that 75,000 will be used. Performance-related incentives linked to sales have been incorporated into the project design.

To perform a market assessment of menstrual hygiene management (MHM) products in two key markets, Ethiopia and India, in order to develop interventions which will increase the use, quality and affordability of MHM products among target consumers.
Using user-centered approaches to increase the adoption of HIV testing and treatment among young men in South Africa.

Project Goal: to reduce morbidity and mortality among PLHIV and to increase financial savings through the delivery of HIVST  STAR Initiative will be implemented by two Grantees, PSI and Society for Family Health South Africa (SFH), respectively. PSI together with consortium partner London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine (LHTM) in five southern African countries including Lesotho, Malawi, Swaziland, Zambia and Zimbabwe, and SFH together with consortium partners University of Witwatersrand-Reproductive Health Institute (Wits-RHI) in South Africa.   The Initiative will be implemented under a single monitoring framework?with a single goal and shared objectives and outputs. Country specific targets will be set under this framework for all six project countries. The Initiative will seize the momentum of STAR Phase 1 to facilitate HIVST scale-up and transition, with the overall goal to reducing HIV-related mortality and morbidity.    Output 1: Supportive environment for introduction and integration of HIVST is established in national policies, strategies, plans, and regulations  Output 2: Selection, adaptation, and scale-up of effective HIVST delivery and linkage models  Output 3: Evidence disseminated and resources to support transition and scale-up identified and mobilized?

IFC, a member of the World Bank Group and the World Bank's Water and Sanitation Program (WSP) are jointly supporting the Kenya Ministry of Health and private sector partners to increase uptake of improved sanitation facilities at scale. Unilever is the donor.  PSI is the prime and SFH is a subawardeee and main implementer of the project.   In the Sunlight Village model, SFH will scale up the pilot conducted in 2014 by delivering behaviour change communications on Oral Hygiene, Nutrition, Hand-washing with soap and ORS/Zinc to treat diarrhea using interpersonal communication agents (IPCAs) and community events.  Shakti Ladies, managed by Unilever's partner Global Business Foundation (GBF), will also sell Unilever's basket of products in the same communities. Market landscaping of HIV self-tests (HIVST) at the global level and in key target markets.  HIVST has been identified as a potential solution to addressing the global HIV testing gap and reaching the UNAIDS-led goal of ?90% of all people living with HIV will know their HIV status by 2020.   PSI will estimate the market potential for HIVST in sub-Saharan Africa and conduct a global market landscape analysis to understand how players across the value chain interact to support the introduction of HIVST, as well as their incentives and capabilities to act within the HIVST market.   Data from landscaping activities will analyze core functions of supply and demand; and be used to generate estimates of HIVST market size, forecast demand and estimate current and future supply.

?PSI will support partners to develop a comprehensive Family Planning Training Toolkit covering counseling and clinical service delivery. The toolkit will include a complete medical overview of reproductive health broken down by advanced modules, including the full range of contraceptive options currently available in Laos. PSI will work with a large group of stakeholders, including the Department of Training and Research (DTR), the Mother and Child Health Center (MCHC), UNFPA, the Lao OBGYN Association, the National Health Sciences University, and the Ministry of Health (MOH) to develop the toolkit. Key stakeholders will participate in two to three technical-level meetings to draft and develop the toolkit. The toolkit will draw heavily from the WHO?s Family Planning: A Global Handbook for Providers which will be translated into Lao and adapted to the Lao context. The toolkit will also include guidelines for supportive supervision and quality assurance audits, including checklists used to evaluate the quality of clinical service delivery and counseling. PSI will also design materials to raise informed demand for family planning options, which will be used at hospitals and health centers to raise awareness about family planning options. PSI will develop flipcharts and other materials, which will be pre-tested among the target audience to ensure they are appealing and easily understandable.?

Reinforcing the achievements made in malaria control in the movements towards elimination of malaria in Madagascar  This program covers funding gaps in the Madagascar Malaria National Strategic Plan. The Global Fund National Strategy Application (NSA) contribution in Phase II will make it possible for the 2015 LLIN mass distribution campaign to be conducted in the 92 high transmission districts in the country, marking a switch to a one time national campaign, as opposed to staggered campaigns that have happened in the past. This grant will provide for 4.2 million LLINs to cover 42 of the targeted districts and PMI will provide for 6.3 million LLINs to cover the remaining 50 targeted districts. In addition, access to Intermittent Preventive Treatment (IPT) will increase, and the grant will also contribute RDTs and ACTs. The Program will focus on the entire population with special focus on specifically on pregnant women and children under five years of age.   PSI replaced UGP as PR for NSA 2 from July 2014-Sep 2015. PSI will primarily focus on the national mass distribution campaign of LLINS scheduled for fall 2015, as well as routine surveillance, and ensuring access to efficient malaria treatment and diagnostics, diffusing IPT for pregnant women. In addition, PSI will be responsible for the Indoor Residual Spraying (IRS) in targeted areas and the training of sprayers in intervention zones. The Principal Recipient will mainly focus on Community Strengthening by training health agents and will support community M&E.  Pact (SR) will mainly focus on Community Strengthening by training health agents and will support community M&E, as well as operational research.

PSI through a sub-award to HC3 will achieve the following objectives by the end of FY15:   -%u200BIncrease the number of free-issue condoms distributed from 6.8 million in FY14 to 6.5 million in FY15 (8 months) to include 6.2 million male condoms and 300,000 female condoms.   -Identify and document 1,500 non-traditional, operating condom outlets which are regularly stocked and monitored.  During FY15, PSI will  -Implement mass media, social media and face-to-face communications -Increase the number of non-traditional outlets giving away and/or selling condoms to youth -Train salespersons/condom distributors in condom outlets to understand the problems faced by young people and the importance of making condoms accessible -Brand youth-appropriate outlets (commercial and non-commercial) with the campaign visual/logo/identity to signify that condoms are available and the distributor/retailer will be non-judgemental and respectful of customers' privacy -Work with private and public sectors to improve distribution networks and condom accessibility
Global Fund project funded to the Zimbabwe Ministry of Health to reduce the toll of Tuberculosis and Malaria in Zimbabwe.

Based on recommendations from the DSM and OHAPP, PASMO/Honduras will use a combination prevention approach to achieve its program objectives. Combination prevention is a framework used for HIV prevention that simultaneously uses the complementary strategies of biomedical, behavioral and structural interventions. For this program, biomedical interventions will include the provision of HTC services and referrals to treatment and care, as well as access to free condoms; behavioral interventions will include BCC activities aiming to increase risk perception, reduce number of partners and improve knowledge and altitudes towards HIV; structural interventions will include activities addressing HIV stigma and discrimination, advocacy for supportive GBV and mental health policies, and capacity building of the DSM to improve ownership, management and sustainability of the program. Over the project's four years, the proposed program will cover 27 of the military's 55 bases, all of which are located along the corridor where HIV prevalence is highest. In year one, PASMO/I Honduras will focus on providing technical assistance to 7 bases offering HCT services ensuring that quality HIV testing and counseling services continue, while building the capacity of the military health personnel to offer HCT services in 8 additional bases through direct service delivery support. Mobile HCT services and HIV prevention activities will continue to be supported in the remaining bases. These 27 bases have been selected in coordination with the DSM, to maximize impact and target resources more effectively. Furthermore, an external quality assurance and proficiency testing program for HIV rapid tests will be conducted in all 15 of the HCT sites.
A multi-country grant for Vector Control - centrally managed by MCSD.

The proposed project will contribute to the goal of achieving HIV epidemic control among military personnel, their families, and civilian communities served by the South African National Defense Force (SANDF) in four districts, namely Ehlanzeni, Tshwane, Capricorn, and Amajuba. Emphasizing capacity building so the SANDF personnel have the skills to improve and sustain long-term Voluntary Medical Male Circumcision (VMMC) programs in the South African Military, the Team will work in close collaboration with SANDF, the National Department of Health (NDoH), Department of Defense (DOD) HIV/AIDS Prevention Program (DHAPP), and relevant Non-Government Organization (NGO) partners and in-country agencies to:  ? Increase demand and uptake of VMMC among the project?s targeted populations with a focus on males 15-34 years of age; ? Improve quality and safety of VMMC services through strengthened Quality Assurance (QA) and monitoring systems; ? Refer and link males who test HIV positive to care and treatment services; ? Improve clinical and human resource capacity of military health unit personnel to provide a comprehensive package of VMMC services.?
Goal to improve nutrition through increased access to improved food sources as well as improved hygeine and sanitation.

Response for HIV and for STIs in Madagascar: an approach involving the populations most exposed in the zones of vulnerability. The target group consists of all vulnerable populations, including MSM, sex workers, PLWH, adolescents and youth, PMTCT, etc.  Expansion of HIV prevention activities to 37 target cities/towns; reduce the # of HIV infections by at least 50% by end of 2017; reduce the proportion of HIV-infected infants born to HIV-positive mothers to 5% by end of 2017; and increase the proportion of PLWH who are alive and on ART at 12 months after treatment initiation to 95% by end of 2017.
The goal of the program is to scale-up and strengthen the delivery of quality HIV and TB/HIV prevention services with facility and community sites.

Stimulating&Shaping the market for HIV self-testing in Africa: two-tier demonstration and evaluation of accuracy and linkage in four countries  The project will catalyze the HIV self-testing (HIVST) market in resource-limited settings in four Southern African countries (Malawi, South Africa, Zambia, and Zimbabwe) by increasing access to HIV oral fluid tests (HIVOFT) for self-testing. As a result of project activities, national testing guidelines and testing algorithms in project countries will address HIVST and at least one HIVOFT packaged and intended for HIVST will be added to a list of approved diagnostic test kits used by major donors.  The following project will be done in two phases over four years. Under Phase 1 (Years 1 and 2), the project will deliver key outputs that make a measurable contribution toward achieving the project's overall impact as described above. If results are satisfactory and further funding is approved, Phase 2 (Years 3 and 4) will achieve the final outputs necessary to achieve impact.

The project goal for Phase II will remain: 'Improvement of knowledge and acceptance of modern FP methods and access to Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) services for youth and rural populations, using a rights-based and gender-sensitive approach.' %u200B%u200BPhase II therefore continues to support the public and private sectors to improve maternal and adolescent health in Malawi by increasing the use of effective FP methods and access to SRH services, especially among WRA, youth, and men in rural and hard-to-reach areas. Phase II also contributes to GoM's overall goal: access to and use of high-quality EHP services improved, in particular in the area of sexual and reproductive health (including the fight against HIV/AIDS).

The project is directed towards: 1) Improving current understanding of malaria epidemiology and elimination readiness in Northern Lao PDR; 2) Strengthening surveillance and response systems to detect and respond to malaria epidemics in Southern Lao; and 3) Assisting CMPE and partners to design and iteratively refine multi-sectorial malaria elimination strategies. These project components will be examined through a diverse set of project activities, including trainings and technical support for data collection and analysis by health staff; retrospective data collection from facilities; and a range of field surveys to determine high-risk groups and risk factors.

Build on the National Strategy Application II Grants' achievements in the Fight to Eliminate Malaria in Madagascar. ??The goal of this project is to reduce malaria-related deaths to zero, and to reduce the test positivity rate to less than 5% in all districts, by then end of 2017. Leverage the African Market Garden (garden) movement to improve gender equity, access to family planning (FP), and nutrition in Niger This project starts from the places where women already gather. In Niger, gardens are emerging as a vibrant and vital place for women to meet, grow nutritious food, and generate income. The project assesses proof of concept for an integrated solution that brings together gender-synchronized approaches, community-based delivery of FP products, and promotion of improved nutrition practices using difference-in-differences estimation to compare intervention and control gardens. Working with women and their male partners, the project team will design an integrated solution that is scalable in the Sahel and in line with Niger?s development priorities.

To assess acceptability and feasibility of self-testing using BB RDTs and to evaluate its accuracy when used by intended users in urban and rural settings in Zimbabwe and Malawi. The formative research is required to inform pilot implementation and introduction of blood-based RDTs for HIV self-testing (HIVST) through different distribution channels that are intended to be evaluated following this initial phase and provide policy and decision makers with evidence to make informed decisions on the most suitable products to be used for this public health intervention.

%u200BThis grant builds on the achivements of the Round 7 and Round 10 consolidated single stream of funding (SSF) malaria grants in South Sudan. The grant will focus on addressing gaps in the key malaria interventions: vector control (ITN mass campaings) and malaria case management (diagnosis and treatment). In alignment with the overarching goals set out in the South Sudan malaria strategic plan, this program is to contribute to the national goal of reducing malaria-related morbidity and mortality by 80 percent of 2013 levels and to reduce malaria parasite prevalence by 50 percent of the 2013 levels by 2021. Population Services International (PSI) seeks to break down barriers to access and use of voluntary, modern contraception among girls and young women (age 15-24), with the aim of reducing unintended pregnancies, reducing unsafe abortions and preventing transmission of sexually transmitted infections (STIs). The Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs is funding PSI to test two innovative models, and two theories of change, to tackle youth and adolescent sexual health issues (2016-2020). The market development approach implemented by PSI in the DRC, Haiti and Mozambique consists in addressing market failures that prevent Sara from accessing the contraceptive products and services she wants and needs. Main approaches used include a thorough landscape analysis to understand how the market is failing Sara (production to use spectrum analysis). This helps ensure that the response is highly context-specific and that programs in each country are geared towards prioritized market players to address the failures identified. PSI also uses user-centered design inspired techniques to gather consumer insights and develop fast prototypes. The Ecosystem development approach, implemented by Triggerise in India and Kenya, consists in improving health the livelihood of micro-entrepreneurs who are incentivized to improve access to contraceptive products and services. Using a peer-to-peer approach that connects consumers to local small businesses, Triggerise gives them the power to both access and deliver aid on their own terms. Building on these relationships, Triggerise uses rewards-based platforms to motivate consumers to make positive choices?helping them to overcome individual barriers as they arise while adding value back into their economies. The project will deliver on 5 outcomes: 1: Increased informed demand for SRH services by girls and young women, 2: Increased access to a wide range of SRH products and services for girls and young women, 3: Improved enabling environment for youth and young women for improving their SRH rights, 4: Create wealth (via improved depth and reach of the ecosystems) and 5: Improve lives (via improved SRHR health outcomes).

This collaboration with PSI Mozambique contributes to two national goals: 1) to increase the contraceptive prevalence rate from 25% to 34% and 2) to increase the use of condoms during risky sex acts of males from 27% to 50%. Social marketing strategies are employed to influence behaviour of all 12 million men and women in the sexually active and reproductive age of 15-49 years, especially of 3 million men engaging in risky sex and 1.2 million women who don’t want to become pregnant but do not yet use any contraceptives. The Social Marketing-concept uses a nationwide network of wholesalers and retailers that sell different types of condoms of the brand Jeito for different prices. Promotional campaigns influence behaviour. At the end of this activity at least 81 million condoms will be sold (about 67% of all condoms sold commercially in Mozambique) and 4 million freely distributed. To improve the use of Sexual and Reproductive Health counseling and services, including family planning and safe abortion services, PSI uses a network of 400 activistas who interact with population in communities, adolescents in schools. The population can be referred to a network of TEM+ clinics, 30 of these are public facilities, and 10 are private. In public facilities SRH services are free. To ensure no one is left behind, a total market approach is employed which includes targeted subsidies for those who cannot afford to pay for condoms and SRHR services. Behaviour change information and communication through media and by‘activistas’and health workers is expected to lead to increased informed demand from youth, men and women for sexual and reproductive health services, counseling and commodities. In the lifetime of this activity almost 1.1 million couples will be protected by modern contraceptives. With these volumes of increased uptake of modern contraceptives and correct and consistent use of condoms, PSI projects to avoid 245,653 unplanned pregnancies, 32,199 new HIV infections and 831 maternal deaths.

Millions of adolescent girls all over the world are facing a limited future because of early marriage (EM), teenage pregnancies and female genital mutilation/cutting (FGM/C). With this project, by changing the attitude of community members and other key persons and informing adolescent girls and boys, adolescents will be empowered to stand up for their sexual reproductive health and rights (SRHR). Through education and economic empowerment, supported by the relevant legislation and policies, the project will give adolescents alternatives beyond EM, teenage pregnancies and FGM/C. The project will be implemented between 2016 and 2020 by Plan Nederland, together with partners Amref, Rutgers, Choice, KIT and the Netherlands’Embassies in the relevant countries. It will be carried out in Ethiopia, Kenya, Zambia, Malawi, Mozambique, Indonesia and Pakistan.

Brecon delivers tailored solutions for cleanrooms, consisting of or behind walls, ceilings, doors, HVAC systems, lighting and other systems such as filter fan units. Cleanrooms are very clean work areas which, for example, the temperature and the concentration of germs and particles is controlled. This cleanroom technology is suitable for use in operating theaters and treatment rooms. In Ghana there is a growing middle class increasingly need to expand and improve care, including good facilities for surgical procedures. Currently, there is a structural shortage of operating rooms of sufficient quality. An OK with a limited quality, resulting in a relatively high concentration of germs in the air, the risk of infections in the patient which often leads to high increases health care costs for post-treatment, re-surgery, medication, etc. The clinics samalla (exists for 33 years ) and Egon Clinic are interested to apply Brecon's technology in their clinics, among others, as it enables them to expand their services and thus sales.

Lamboo Special Sales focuses on Mobile Preventive treatments (mammography TB, diabetes, etc) mobile specialized treatments (MRI PET / CT and CT Surgery Cath Lab) and mobile disaster management (complete mobile hospitals).Through the investment study will analyze and examine whether it is feasible to make an investment in an assembly and service center of mobile and modular hospitals in South Africa. The study, the technical and financial-economic feasibility to demonstrate the investment.In 2013/2014 Lamboo has had contact Mzansi Lifecare in South Africa due the purchase of a mobile medical unit Lamboo. To carry out this cost recovery is Lamboo through Mzansi Lifecare come in contact with Rapid Truck Bodies. The mobile medical unit has been developed in its entirety in the Netherlands, produced and assembled (including the procurement and mounting of medical equipment in the unit). Rapid Truck Bodies provided the truck and substructure. The mobile unit is entirely exported to South Africa after Rapid Truck Bodies and substructure underneath the truck has mounted. This cooperation has been satisfactory but for cost reasons not be repeated in this manner. Lamboo would like to investigate whether it is feasible to set up through a joint venture structure with Rapid Truck Bodies an assembly and service facility in South Africa where Lamboo in the Netherlands produces the structure of the mobile units and assembles and that the joint venture in South Africa in addition to the delivery and assembly of the truck chassis and the local medical equipment purchases and the electrical connections for in-mount units.

The Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS) is the primary global multilateral agency responding to HIV/AIDS. Its mandate is to provide international coordination, leadership, strategic guidance and advocacy to mobilise global resources for the HIV response.  Funding of $7.5 million under this investment represents Australia's 2015 annual contribution, to support the UNAIDS Strategy 2011-15 and the work of the UNAIDS Regional Support Team for Asia and the Pacific. This investment is guided by a strategic partnership framework.
Short-term TA with expertise in pharmaceutcial sector to assist Zambian Ministry of Health with the Mid-Term Review of the National Health Strategic Plan 2012-2016

The United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) promotes the right of every woman, man and child to enjoy a life of health and equal opportunity.  Funding under this investment  represents Australia's core funding to UNFPA and supports UNFPA to deliver targeted maternal health services, including family planning and reproductive health, HIV/AIDS prevention, gender based violence and gender equality programs in key countries in regions where Australia has an interest. The total value of this investment is $15.0 million expensed during financial year 2013-14.

Funding under this investment  provides support through the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) to improve the availability, quality and use of data on children with disabilities. UNICEF will partner with the Washington Group on Disability Statistics (WG) to complete a set of survey questions to provide international standardised data on children with disabilities. This funding will also support the development of a second set of survey questions to understand the barriers and facilitators to children with disability accessing quality education. The survey is intended to be used to capture statistics on children with disability attending school and those who are not. Once completed these survey questions will be used to improve data collection on children with disabilities in UNICEF’s Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), one of the largest global sources of internationally comparable data on the situation of children and women. Funding also supports the production manuals which will support the implementation of these two surveys and provide advice on how to design and plan child disability data collection programs from start to finish. UNICEF will work with National Statistics offices (NSO) to ensure: 1) they have the skills to use both surveys to collect the right data; 2) they can analyse the results to inform future policies and programmes; and 3) to promote the use of the surveys. UNICEF will prioritise implementation in the Asia-Pacific region. The total value of this investment is $1.5 million over 2 years, starting 2013-14.

The World Health Organization (WHO) is a specialized agency of the United Nations that is concerned with international public health, specifically: to reduce the health, social and economic burden of communicable diseases; combat HIV, tuberculosis and malaria; reduce morbidity, mortality and improve health during key stages of life including pregnancy, childbirth, neonatal period, childhood and adolescence, and improved sexual and reproductive health; and reduce the health consequences of emergencies, disasters, crises and conflicts. Funding under this initiative represents Australia's core contribution to the WHO and is valued at $20.0 million over the 2013-14 financial year.

UNAIDS aims to lead, strengthen and support an expanded response to HIV and AIDS that includes preventing transmission of HIV, providing care and support to those already living with the virus, reducing the vulnerability of individuals and communities to HIV and alleviating the impact of the epidemic. UNAIDS seeks to prevent the HIV/AIDS epidemic from becoming a severe pandemic. Funding under this investment represents Australia's annual contribution valued at $7.2 million expensed during the 2013-14 financial year.

The United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) Global Programme to Enhance Reproductive Health Commodity Security (GPERHCS) aims to improve sexual, reproductive and maternal health by increasing access to affordable, quality reproductive health commodities. GPERHCS provides financial support for countries to manage supplies of reproductive health commodities and strengthen their health systems. Australia's contribution to GPERHCS will support activities with a focus in the Asia Pacific region which will help countries in the region to improve access to a reliable supply of contraceptives, condoms, medicine and equipment for family planning, prevention of HIV and other sexually transmitted infections and maternal health. The total value of this investment is $2.95 million expensed in the 2013-14 financial year.

The United Nations Population Funds (UNFPA) mission is to deliver a world where every pregnancy is wanted, every birth is safe, and every young person's potential is fulfilled. UNFPA assists countries in collecting, analysing, and disseminating population data and supports policies on gender and maternal health.  Funding under this investment  represents Australia's core funding to UNFPA and supports UNFPA to deliver targeted maternal health services, including family planning and reproductive health, HIV/AIDS prevention, gender based violence and gender equality programs in key countries in regions where Australia has an interest. The total value of this investment is $15.4 million expensed during financial year 2014-15.

The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis (TB) and Malaria (Global Fund) was established in 2002 by the international community under the patronage of United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan and works to attract and disperse additional resources to prevent and treat AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria. A particular focus of Australia's cooperation with the Global Fund is the elimination of drug-resistant strains of Malaria in the Mekong sub-region and TB in Papua New Guinea. Funding under this investment represents Australia's forth replenishment contribution to the Global Fund and is valued at $203.0 million over 3 years starting 2014-15.

ADB is reinforcing the efforts of Government of India to improve the health of people who live in cities, especially the poor. The Supporting National Urban Health Mission project is helping provide basic health services, such as immunizations, . The project is strengthening health systems across cities and towns to deliver quality health services for all, with a particular focus on the poor and vulnerable. The project is improving the networks of primary health facilities in urban areas and introducing a quality assurance mechanism for them. It is also helping to improve planning, management, and innovation, in order to bring best practices to city clinics and health centers. The financing for the project is being disbursed based on the achievement of results, including more births in health facilities and higher childhood immunization rates.

The Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Health Security Project is composed of (i) four loans to Cambodia, the Lao PDR, Myanmar, and Viet Nam (CLMV); and (ii) a grant to the Lao PDR. The project builds on previous and ongoing interventions focusing on communicable disease control (CDC) in Cambodia, the Lao PDR, and Viet Nam; and now including Myanmar.The impact will be GMS public health security strengthened. The outcome will be GMS health system performance with regard to health security improved. The project has three outputs. Output 1: Regional cooperation and communicable disease control in border areas improved. Output 2: National disease surveillance and outbreak response systems strengthened. Output 3: Laboratory services and hospital infection prevention and control improved.

The Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Health Security Project is composed of (i) four loans to Cambodia, the Lao PDR, Myanmar, and Viet Nam (CLMV); and (ii) a grant to the Lao PDR. The project builds on previous and ongoing interventions focusing on communicable disease control (CDC) in Cambodia, the Lao PDR, and Viet Nam; and now including Myanmar.The impact will be GMS public health security strengthened. The outcome will be GMS health system performance with regard to health security improved. The project has three outputs. Output 1: Regional cooperation and communicable disease control in border areas improved. Output 2: National disease surveillance and outbreak response systems strengthened. Output 3: Laboratory services and hospital infection prevention and control improved.

The Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Health Security Project is composed of (i) four loans to Cambodia, the Lao PDR, Myanmar, and Viet Nam (CLMV); and (ii) a grant to the Lao PDR. The project builds on previous and ongoing interventions focusing on communicable disease control (CDC) in Cambodia, the Lao PDR, and Viet Nam; and now including Myanmar.The impact will be GMS public health security strengthened. The outcome will be GMS health system performance with regard to health security improved. The project has three outputs. Output 1: Regional cooperation and communicable disease control in border areas improved. Output 2: National disease surveillance and outbreak response systems strengthened. Output 3: Laboratory services and hospital infection prevention and control improved.

To contribute to the improvement in the correct use of quality assured essential medicines in both the public and private health care systems, through the implementation of specific activities, aimed at strengthening rational drug use in Zambia, in line with the national objectives on drug use.

The Asia- Pacific and the Global Fund- An Aidspan Regional Report (the report) will provide a concise yet comprehensive portrait of the Asia Pacific region, examining the underlying public health, human rights and vulnerability issues that could challenge or compromise the effectiveness of Global Fund-supported programming. The analysis will review the major fiscal constraints and health system capacity issues that underlie many of the region’s problems, mapping those issues and threats as closely as is possible to the Global Fund supported programs.An accompanying short film will be developed which will raise awareness of key challenges faced in ensuring Global Fund grants are spent as efficiently and effectively as possible in the Pacific region in a visually striking and intellectually engaging way.The short film will bring to life the human story behind problems of accountability and transparency in Papua New Guinea, adding impact to Aidspan’s written report and engaging a wide audience with the issues at stake.

The Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS) is the primary global multilateral agency responding to HIV/AIDS. Its mandate is to provide international coordination, leadership, strategic guidance and advocacy to mobilise global resources for the HIV response. Funding of $4.5 million under this investment represents Australia's 2016 annual contribution, to support the work of the UNAIDS Regional Support Team for Asia and the Pacific. This investment is guided by a strategic partnership framework.

The Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Health Security Project is composed of (i) four loans to Cambodia, the Lao PDR, Myanmar, and Viet Nam (CLMV); and (ii) a grant to the Lao PDR.
