Output 1: Regional cooperation and communicable disease control in border areas improved. Output 2: National disease surveillance and outbreak response systems strengthened.  Output 3: Laboratory services and hospital infection prevention and control improved.

The United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) is a key organisation supporting progress towards global achievement of the health and gender equality targets of the Sustainable Development Goals. It assists countries in collecting, analysing and disseminating population data, and supports developing policies and programs on gender and maternal health, particularly reproductive health, including family planning, safe motherhood, HIV/AIDS prevention, gender-based violence and promoting gender equality. UNFPA also provides technical guidance, training and support to its partners in the field. Australia provides UNFPA with annual core voluntary contributions (AUD $9.24 million in 2016) to support the implementation of its Strategic Plan 2014-2017.

This research will look at the extent to which Social Protection systems in Asia, the Pacific and sub-Saharan Africa are inclusive of people with disabilities.The research will be conducted in two phases.The first will identify and document examples of good practice in disability inclusive social protection systems in Asia, the Pacific and sub-Saharan Africa.The second phase of the study will assess the extent to which social protection systems in two selected case study countries (Nepal and Vietnam) address the needs of people with disabilities, identify and document good practice and consider how good practice examples could be transferred to other Asia - Pacific countries. The research will provide related guidance.
Support to strengthen preparedness and response to disease outbreaks and emergencies with health consequences - global.

The United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) Supplies Programme, is the UNFPA’s sexual and reproductive health commodities procurement and distribution program.  It is supporting 46 countries to tackle high maternal death rates, low rates of contraceptive use and a growing unmet need for family planning. Since 2008, UNFPA Supplies’ efforts have increased access to, choice of, and use of modern contraceptives. They have also enhanced the capacity of national health systems to manage these supplies and to provide family planning, maternal health and HIV-prevention services.
Two evaluations of the MDGi programme; one at mid-term and one ex-post.

Sexual and reproductive health complications are the leading cause of death and disability among women and girls globally. Despite the number of humanitarian emergencies increasing, the area remains drastically underfunded leaving women and girls vulnerable to preventable illness and death. An independent review of SPRINT II found that the model is fit for purpose and should be expanded. Therefore, Australia is developing a third phase of the SPRINT program which will continue to focus on Sexual and reproductive health related emergency preparedness and ensures integration of the Minimum Initial Services Package (MISP). SPRINT is carried out my IPPF Member Associations. The development of the third phase of SPRINT will determine if the three activities of SPRINT II will continue;1.	Disaster risk reduction / enabling environment: SPRINT advocates for governments and organisations to integrate SRH in to their responses;2.	Emergency preparedness / capacity development: SPRINT trains first responders to implement MISP during a humanitarian crisis; and3.	Emergency response: SPRINT II provides emergency response funding to service providers to meet lifesaving SRH needs.

The World Health Organization (WHO) is a technical United Nations agency which sets global norms and standards in health. Australia provides WHO with annual core voluntary contributions in a flexible manner to support the WHO’s General Programme of Work. Australian Government funding contributes to: strengthening health systems; achieving better health outcomes and identifying and addressing emerging regional health issues. Funding of $12.4 million under this investment represents Australia's 2016 voluntary core contribution to WHO. This investment is guided by a strategic partnership framework.

This work relates to the construction of the National Medicines Quality Control Laboratory (NMQCL) and Office Complex for the Zambia Medicines Regulatory Authority (ZAMRA), in accordance with the technical specifications of the tender dossier

Applicants' aim is to build a prototype of a cheap ultrasound device that will help midwives to assess whether a pregnant woman should be referred to hospital. If successful the project should result in reduced maternal disability and death through early detection of potentially dangerous pregnancies. The automatic detection software is the most innovative part of the project. The anticipated business model is described as a fee per scan model.The project will:1. train midwives to use this basic ultrasound device,2. collect these ultrasound image data and use them to design software that assists midwives to use the device properly and automatically detect gestational age and potentially dangerous situations like placenta previa, breech and multiple pregnancies.

Applicants tackle the last kilometers in the delivery of medical goods to health posts in Ghana, which is often hampered by the bad condition of roads by creating a custom-made unmanned aerial system (drone) for the transport of essential medical goods (both for emergencies and for stock supply) by air from a hospital to a (remote) health post. Once functional, this system will address access to better SRHR and to drugs/vaccines to combat poverty related diseases. The technical goal is to produce a functional prototype and test it in Ghana. Meanwhile, business models for future production, exploitation and maintenance of drones are investigated. Other partners focus on (flight) rules and  local acceptance. This project is part of a larger Master Plan.

BLISS4Midwives is part of the TNO programme BLISS and aims to combine existing point-of-care diagnostics into one suitcase-like modular device that will allow midwives in Ghana to test on the spot whether a pregnant woman suffers from eg. (pre)eclampsia and possibly other complications. The device is also fitted with a (tablet) screen and software that provide user instructions and decision support (whether a referral to hospital is needed). The project aims to produce 10 prototypes and train at least 20 midwives in the use of it. The device will be tested in Ghana on at least 500 pregnant women.

Pneumonia is the leading cause of child mortality under five, resulting in 1.1 million deaths annually. The partners in this project are working on a cost-effective technology that will support health workers at the Bottom of the Pyramid to accurately assess fast breathing rate in children under 5 and support a better diagnosis of pneumonia: the Childrens Automated Respiration Monitor (ChARM). The device will provide clinical decision support to frontline health workers during their diagnosis of pneumonia and support the prescription of antibiotics for only those children that have fast breathing.

PharmAccess, Kwara State Government and Hygeia have been working together with local communities and traditional leaders since 2007 to implement the Kwara State Health Insurance Programme. A major challenge has been building the capacity of the primary health care centres to deliver sexual and reproductive health care and treatment for poverty-related diseases. To address the human capacity issues of the primary care centres, mHealth solutions involving telemedicine and medical call center will be established. Primary care centers in rural Kwara will be linked to district hospitals, which will be connected to the teaching hospital and the specialized medical center in Ilorin (capital of Kwara State) and Hygeia hospitals in Lagos.

A feasibility study to examine viability of a high quality maternal and newborn health package including technologies and services. The activities will be concentrated around the Dhulikhel Hospital, a not-for-profit, non-government tertiary level hospital, that runs 18 primary level Outreach Clinics and also provides (para)medical training services.  The catchment population is the approx. 179 thousand women of the reproductive age and newborns living in the districts of Kavrepalanchok and Sindhupalchok, of which over one fifth (21,69%) is living in poverty.

Early detection is the most promising strategy to reduce the enormous worldwide burden of tuberculosis (TB). The partners in this project have developed a breakthrough technology, CAD4TB, software that automatically provides information about patients who should proceed with the more expensive and time-consuming X-ray test. The demonstration will include a complete platform called CAD4TBCloud that can be used with any digital X-ray machine anywhere in the world, running  locally and in the cloud. The platform will be tested in Kigali, Rwanda, and Dhaka, Bangladesh.

A pilot study to assess the feasibility for the development of a safe and cost-effective vaccine (Sm-TSP-2) against schistosomiasis tailored to the paediatric target population, more than 200 million people in most of the resource-deprived regions of the devloping world. The outcome is an innovatively developed and licensed vaccin by 2025 with an efficacy of 40-50%. To achieve this, a worldwide partnership is formed.

This demonstration project will establish an innovative district-based (sexual reproductive) health entrepreneurship model. Local entrepreneurs will conduct outreach health promotion and offer a wide range of reliable and affordable high quality medicines and health products. A central district stock management system and supply chain will be operated and 50 Accredited Drug Stores (franchise) operational at village level. They are supported by 50 Community Health Workers who are responsible for health promotion and outreach supply services. Via innovative e-health applications the trained Health workers and drug stores will provide interactive health information on various topics like contraceptives, Hiv/Aids, safe motherhood, sexuality and malaria.

The Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Health Security Project is composed of (i) four loans to Cambodia, the Lao PDR, Myanmar, and Viet Nam (CLMV); and (ii) a grant to the Lao PDR. The project builds on previous and ongoing interventions focusing on communicable disease control (CDC) in Cambodia, the Lao PDR, and Viet Nam; and now including Myanmar.The impact will be GMS public health security strengthened. The outcome will be GMS health system performance with regard to health security improved. The project has three outputs. Output 1: Regional cooperation and communicable disease control in border areas improved. Output 2: National disease surveillance and outbreak response systems strengthened. Output 3: Laboratory services and hospital infection prevention and control improved.

Each year over 2500 women die from complications related to pregnancy and childbirth in Burkina Faso as reported by a 2009 report of Amnesty International and based on data by the Ministry of Health. Most of these deaths could be avoided if adequate obstetric care was available and accessible. Additionally according to UNFPA/WHO estimates for every woman who dies from complications related to childbirth approximately 20 more suffer from injuries infections and disabilities that can result in temporary or lifelong social and economic exclusion. The main and most important causes of the maternal mortality and morbidity and infant mortality is the lack of adequate healthcare services, including a need for both health infrastructure (healthcare facilities equipment etc) and skilled human resources.The Ministry of Health of Burkina Faso recently created six new health district to bring healthcare closer to the population. Five of these new districts have been selected for the project because they currently do not have a the facility for comprehensive emergency obstetric and neonatal care. These five health districts are the districts of Mangodara in the Cascades Region (southwest Burkina Faso) the districts of Karangasso-vigué and Lena in the Hauts-Bassins Region (also southwest) and the districts of Manni and Gayéri in the Eastern Region.

The Medicines for Malaria Venture (MMV) - MMV’s mission is to reduce the burden of malaria in disease-endemic countries by discovering, developing and delivering new, effective and affordable antimalarial drugs to cure and protect vulnerable populations.

DNDi’s mission is to improve the quality of life and the health of people suffering from neglected diseases using an alternative model to develop drugs for these diseases and by ensuring equitable access to new and field-relevant health tools.

The TB Alliance’s mission is to dramatically impact the tuberculosis pandemic by developing new, significantly improved, faster-acting and affordable TB treatments that are available to those who need them.
IPM’s mission is to provide women with safe, effective and affordable products they can use to prevent HIV and protect their sexual and reproductive health.

In Moldova, young people face various health challenges which are currently not adequately addressed by health services. To improve this situation, Youth Friendly Health Services started as pilots in 2005 and are being scaled-up by the Ministry of Health since 2011, with the support of SDC. The project is focused on improving the quality and enhancing the comprehensiveness of the services, as well as on the community support for young people to adopt a healthier lifestyle and seek assistance from health services.

In Moldova, young people face various health challenges which are currently not adequately addressed by health services. To improve this situation, Youth Friendly Health Services started as pilots in 2005 and are being scaled-up by the Ministry of Health since 2011, with the support of SDC. The project is focused on improving the quality and enhancing the comprehensiveness of the services, as well as on the community support for young people to adopt a healthier lifestyle and seek assistance from health services.

In Moldova, young people face various health challenges which are currently not adequately addressed by health services. To improve this situation, Youth Friendly Health Services started as pilots in 2005 and are being scaled-up by the Ministry of Health since 2011, with the support of SDC. The project is focused on improving the quality and enhancing the comprehensiveness of the services, as well as on the community support for young people to adopt a healthier lifestyle and seek assistance from health services.

On the 8th August 2014 the World Health Organisation (WHO) announced the Ebola outbreak in West Africa (affecting Sierra Leone, Guinea, Liberia and Nigeria). The outbreak is the largest the world has ever seen and WHO estimates up to 20,000 cases over the next six to nine months without intensified control measures. Following the announcement the WHO formally requested Australian support to assist with the WHO consolidated appeal to respond to the outbreak. Through the WHO Ebola response roadmap which identifies immediate needs and priorities, funding under this investment contributes to Australia's response to the Ebola outbreak and will provide support for human resources and medical expertise, logistics, supplies and equipment and food and water for those in affected regions. The total value of this investment is $12.0 million expensed in the 2014-15 financial year.

In Ethiopia there is a significant, though relatively small, market demand for camel milk by two groups: local ethnics (mainly in Addis) and local health groups. At present the milk is brought raw from the (far) country side, which bears high risks of freshness and hygiene. The project will be located in Debre Berhan where the partners will set up a nucleus farm (200 ha) with camels and cows. In addition, they will work with about fifty nomadic smallholders/shepherds. The applicant is a Kenyan company, established and run by a German expert. The local partner and the applicant together will set up a joint venture. The project aims to produce good quality, preserved camel and cow milk and sell it to local consumers and in the wider region (Somalia and Northern African countries). The applied pascalisation technology is based on killing of germs (as heat does) through excessive pressure and is supposed to result in a longer shelf life for the milk (cooled at least 25 - 40 days), to fix more vitamins, unsaturated (healthy) fats and important enzymes while its taste is very close to fresh, raw milk. Furthermore, pascalisation is less energy consuming than pasteurisation or sterilisation and will be HALAL certified.

Applicant HEAP Research BV is specialised in the development of medical services in emerging markets. Local partner Medison Ltd owns and operates a number of privatized outpatient clinics in Georgia. The partners will set up a joint venture according to Georgian law. The project will be located in one of the local partner's medical centres in Tbilisi.In cooperation with a team of medical specialists from the Academic Medical Centre (AMC) in Amsterdam, rehabilitation centre Roessingh in Enschede and the HEAP/Artmed clinic in Yerevan, Armenia, the partners plan to open a clinic with a comprehensive approach to rehabilitation care. The focus of the clinic will be on patients suffering from orthopaedic trauma, stroke, and cerebral palsy. The concept is completely new to Georgia. Patients in need of the care offered by the new joint venture now have to go abroad to receive treatment. In practice, most of them receive no professional care at all. Nineteen physicians, three doctors and a number of nurses will be trained and supported by professionals from leading institutions in the field of rehabilitative care in the Netherlands. In total, the project will create 38 new jobs.

The partners will establish a facility in Laos to produce herbal food supplements and cosmetics.Currently, Laos sells a lot of herbs to Vietnam and China and imports a lot of finished herbal products.The partners are already active in the herbal sector. The applicant Greater Pharma Company Ltd from Thailand is producing herbal medicines in Thailand and the local partner Viengthong Pharma Company Ltd distributes (herbal) medicines and medical equipment in Laos including products of the applicant. Partners know each other well and have all the knowledge and experience to implement the project.The partners will establish a joint venture that will be located in Vientiane.The project will work with at least fifty outgrowers to secure the year-round supply of the required herbs. This is new for the country where, currently, a lot of herbs are collected in the forests.The project will add value to the herbs in Laos and will introduce the GMP standard in the herbal industry. It will be the first Laos producer of herbal food supplements and cosmetics.

Quinine is processed and marketed into various derivatives and alkaloids. The processing is fairly sophisticated and there is only a limited number of production units in the world.The production outside Europe is mainly concentrated in Indonesia and India. Indonesia has two extraction facilities, Kimia Farma and PT SiL. Arnold Suhr Netherlands has an exclusive co-operation with Kimia Farma.However, the production facility of Kimia is situated in the heart of the city of Bandung and the Indonesian government has decided that the location in Bandung should be closed. Therefore, the applicant Arnold Suhr Netherlands and the local partner Bionexx are interested in the establishment of an extraction unit in combination with investments in new plantations in Madagascar in order to better control the quality of the bark (which is presently mainly produced in DR Congo) and to create a sustainable growth of the supply of bark.Main activity of the project will be the processing of cinchona bark into quinine derivates for the international market. Initially, a limited part of the bark will be obtained from local production in Madagascar, a major part will still be imported. Local production will be actively promoted under the project through training and technical advice in the establishment of cinchona plantation and the establishment of nurseries for improved cinchona seedlings in the area of Fianarantsoa where the Artemisia processing plant of the local partner is located. The quinine processing plant will have a capacity of 1,400 Mtons of cinchona bark a year to produce 73 Mtons of totaquina (the quinine precursor). The capacity of the nursery to be established will allow the production of 150,000 seedlings annually for the plantation of 75 ha.

In Bolivia there is no possibility to obtain an MRI scan at the internationally required standard level of 1.5 Tesla. Only a few MRI scanners can be found, using outdated technology up to 0.35 Tesla. Low resolution MRI means low quality, as such less functional for most medical indications. Details are missed, about 75% of the injuries cannot be diagnosed by these low-quality MRI. The investments in high-end MRI scans however are too expensive for most hospitals. This project will provide a solution by starting a diagnostic MRI service centre with two mobile MRI units to be parked next to hospitals or outpatient clinics. The centre will provide online diagnostic reports and pictures to the referral doctors, who can deliver medical advice to their patients. Cost of the service will be paid by insurance companies, private hospitals or the patients themselves. The joint venture will work with a social pricing system to assure access also for the poorest people, as a result prices will range between € 1 to € 150 per scan. The company will have a maximum capacity of 9,000 MRI scans and diagnostic conclusions per year. The centre will be based in La Paz and the mobile units will rotate within the poorer neighbourhoods of La Paz, El Alto and surrounding villages. The joint venture company is formed between Hospital Arco Iris in La Paz and Qmed BV of the Netherlands. Through this MRI diagnostic centre the health sector of Bolivia will be uplifted, enabling better medical diagnostic conclusions.

The applicant, Advanced Processes Inc., is a US firm established in 1998, employing fifteen staff. Advanced Processes Inc. is specialised in waste processing and electricity generation. The local partner Caltech Ventures, is a Ghanaian firm established in 2005. Currently, Caltech grows cassava for production of cassava flour but in the near future also for production of ethanol. Caltech owns 3,400 ha of land of which 250 ha has been planted with cassava. The partners plan to generate renewable energy from cassava waste and municipal waste in the Volta region. The partners will set up a joint venture with equal shareholding and will establish a 600 kW waste to energy plant. The power produced by the joint venture will be sold to the national electricity provider and to Caltech. This will be the first gasification plant in Ghana. Cassava waste will be collected from cassava farmers and municipal waste will be sorted and briquetted at the local landfill site. The electricity off take is guaranteed by the Public Utility and by the local partner. Fertiliser pellets will be produced as a by-product and will be sold to Caltech and other agro-communities.

Colombian applicant Centro de Ortodoncia y Ortopedia Maxilar y Rehabilitación Oral S.A. and local partner Asistencia de Servicios Empresariales y Financieros S.A. are both dental clinics. In Nicaragua and other Latin American countries, dentists face shortages of high quality dental prostheses such as crowns, teeth and implants. As a result, these products are imported from the United States at a high cost for patients. At the same time, Nicaragua boasts well-skilled labour and a lack of technical job opportunities. The partners have identified the business opportunity to establish the first advanced dental laboratory in Nicaragua that will substitute imports by producing high quality dental lab products at a lower cost.The company will create 62 jobs in Nicaragua, of which 70% is medium and high-level and 60% are women. Through collaboration with the Association for Persons with Physical Disabilities, 10 technical positions will be filled by persons with reduced physical abilities, a group that is facing strong discrimination in the job market. The joint venture will implement an intensive training programme and introduce new technology in Nicaragua. Growth after the project is expected, with reinvestments that result in total employment of 97 persons (79 medium&high-level). Partners will establish a joint venture. The project will bring new technology to Nicaragua and dental products will become available at a more affordable price than imported products. Furthermore, the project will generate medium and high level jobs for people with a technical background.

Poultry consumption is on the rise in Nepal, although still low compared to neighbouring countries. An estimated 230 million chicken are raised in backyards every year. Seventy percent of the total stock dies in the rainy season due to avian flu (AF) and Newcastle disease (ND). The major poultry farms (producing another 70 million chicken) are able to vaccinate their stock. Because Newcastle vaccines are thermos-unstable, they cannot be used in remote areas where the majority of Nepal's rural population lives. Paid for by the Australian Government, a thermo stable ND vaccine was developed in Australia. This vaccine survives thirty days of tropical temperatures and is affordable for smallholders. The local partner, Intrepid Nepal Pvt. Ltd is a company of thirty highly qualified employees that focuses on Molecular Diagnostics Platforms. Their area of work is detection of pathogens, human and animal. One of their activities is epidemical research. In this way, they got a clear picture of the ND problem and decided to produce this thermos-stable vaccine using the Australian seeds, that are non-commercially available. In the poultry production chain, such a vaccine is the missing link. As this is to be the first commercial production of a vaccine from this seed, the Australian government is eager to facilitate this by providing expertise and seeds free of costs. USAID and an NGO have already pledged to buy thermos-stable vaccine for seven million chicken and resell them to smallholders. The business includes diagnosing whether it makes sense to vaccinate in a certain area, determining the ND strain rampant and the production of the vaccine itself. In order to get sufficient starting capital, they were introduced to the applicant by Dutch businessmen active in Nepal. The applicant, Aleven BV, is an asset manager that invests on behalf of his Dutch clients in food and health related companies in Nepal, Georgia and the Philippines. The other project partner, One to Watch BV, is a developer of Nepali companies active in food and health. The three partners will start a joint venture that enables Intrepid to start the production of vaccine on their premises.

Pork meat is widely consumed in Uganda however the sector is not organised and underdeveloped. Modern husbandry techniques are lacking and the small rural farmers are keeping pigs with genetics originating from breeds imported almost twenty years ago. This project will address two opportunities which have been reported for the pig sector in Uganda: 1) Pig breeding and pig multiplication centres - the growing foreign community in Uganda has increased the demand for pork and bacon and 2) Abattoirs for pigs. The production and sales of (premium quality) pork meat targeting the foreign and upper class of Uganda is the projects' main activity. The partners are convinced that the first critical steps of progress in a country like Uganda would be improving production techniques with improved (and not top-end) genetic material and building a know-how base. Applicant, SUIN, from Belgium is involved in pig production since 1995. The company's founder has developed a special pig breed called Duroc d'olives and runs a closed pig farm with 1,200 sows producing fattening pigs. Local partner, Greenfields, from Uganda has a successful track record of over ten years in the fishery sector through a previous PSOM Tilapia project. Third partner Marc Thyssen is a Belgian agricultural engineer experienced in the animal feed business and in meat processing. Together, the three partners possess all knowledge and experience needed to operate the new farm which will be Uganda's first AI centre, pig abattoir, breeding farm and special pig feed formulation laboratory. Animal Welfare conditions, implemented along EU standards, will get full attention through cooperation with a local Pig Farmers association and will be monitored by the International Livestock Research Institute.

Leishmaniasis is one of the most significant vector-borne diseases worldwide, with more than 2 million new cases recorded every year. In South America, both cutaneous leishmaniasis (skin infections) and the more severe visceral form of the disease (affecting vital organs) are emerging in many countries and expanding northward and southward. The border areas of Argentina, Brazil, and Paraguay have the highest burden of the disease in the region. Its emergence is strongly associated with environmental and anthropogenic changes, or pollution caused by humans.This research project aims to enhance prevention and control responses to the disease's emergence and spread in the bordering regions through multi-country collaboration. The project team will develop evidence-based interventions which can be adapted to diverse socio-cultural and ecological settings. More specifically, researchers will:-analyze social, environmental, and biological drivers causing the emergence or re-emergence of leishmaniasis;-assess how the disease is distributed and spread in time and space in the common borders between the three countries;-identify and develop innovative and effective ecohealth-based prevention strategies involving communities, researchers, and decision-makers from different jurisdictional levels and sectors; and,-improve vector and leishmaniasis control strategies in the three countries by strengthening cross-country collaboration, skills building, and knowledge exchange.In the area under study, different forms of transmission occur in a diversity of settings, ranging from forest to urban ecosystems, and from work to domestic environments. The region also has a diverse population, including the Guarani people, migrants (transient and permanent settlements), and tourists.Researchers will study biological, environmental, and social variables associated with disease transmission risks in different types of landscapes. In each country, a specific set of interventions will be developed to address the disease's emergence and spread. The project will engage researchers and decision-makers from the three countries to respond to public health authorities'explicit demands to improve the effectiveness of control programs. Participants will include decision-makers from the local, subnational, and national levels of the three countries, and technical experts from the Pan-American Health Organization. This will enhance uptake of results and implementation of multi-sector prevention and control strategies. It will also help ensure that results are replicated and scaled up in other high-risk areas of the sub-region. The work is expected to set the foundation for novel control strategies and programs in the three countries and inform possible regional responses.

Leishmaniasis is one of the most significant vector-borne diseases worldwide, with more than 2 million new cases recorded every year. In South America, both cutaneous leishmaniasis (skin infections) and the more severe visceral form of the disease (affecting vital organs) are emerging in many countries and expanding northward and southward. The border areas of Argentina, Brazil, and Paraguay have the highest burden of the disease in the region. Its emergence is strongly associated with environmental and anthropogenic changes, or pollution caused by humans.This research project aims to enhance prevention and control responses to the disease's emergence and spread in the bordering regions through multi-country collaboration. The project team will develop evidence-based interventions which can be adapted to diverse socio-cultural and ecological settings. More specifically, researchers will:-analyze social, environmental, and biological drivers causing the emergence or re-emergence of leishmaniasis;-assess how the disease is distributed and spread in time and space in the common borders between the three countries;-identify and develop innovative and effective ecohealth-based prevention strategies involving communities, researchers, and decision-makers from different jurisdictional levels and sectors; and,-improve vector and leishmaniasis control strategies in the three countries by strengthening cross-country collaboration, skills building, and knowledge exchange.In the area under study, different forms of transmission occur in a diversity of settings, ranging from forest to urban ecosystems, and from work to domestic environments. The region also has a diverse population, including the Guarani people, migrants (transient and permanent settlements), and tourists.Researchers will study biological, environmental, and social variables associated with disease transmission risks in different types of landscapes. In each country, a specific set of interventions will be developed to address the disease's emergence and spread. The project will engage researchers and decision-makers from the three countries to respond to public health authorities'explicit demands to improve the effectiveness of control programs. Participants will include decision-makers from the local, subnational, and national levels of the three countries, and technical experts from the Pan-American Health Organization. This will enhance uptake of results and implementation of multi-sector prevention and control strategies. It will also help ensure that results are replicated and scaled up in other high-risk areas of the sub-region. The work is expected to set the foundation for novel control strategies and programs in the three countries and inform possible regional responses.

Afghanistan has a National Health Service (NHS), providing free treatment and medicines. The total NHS budget for Afghanistan is half the budget of, for instance, the Maastricht University hospital. As a result patients have to bribe their way into the health chain, from guard to surgeon, to receive medical treatment. Private practices are available, often run by the same doctors who work in the NHS hospitals. Patients who can afford it fly to India and Pakistan for treatment.The local partner is a medical doctor who established a small diagnostic clinic specialised in endoscopic diagnostics. Forty patients are treated daily for gastroenterological problems like ulcers etc.In 2006, he and the Dutch applicant planned to set up a small private hospital for digestive diseases (gastroenterology), providing diagnostics and treatment including operations. For the last six years, the partners carefully prepared for the establishment of the hospital. To provide for the management skills required, the local partner sent a family member to get a MBA in health care administration in India, and he himself worked for one year in Iran as head of a laboratory of a major hospital. Other family members were sent to different relevant courses. Gradually, he extended his network to other hospitals, mostly in India, to ensure possibilities for training and second opinion. In 2011, he acquired a plot to build the hospital. The core business is to be gastroenterology, but as these diseases are often related with other diseases, other medical specialists are required as well. As they are not available in nearby hospitals, these specialists will have to be recruited for this hospital on a freelance basis. Telemedicine facilities reduce the need for patients to go abroad for a second opinion. Average treatment costs an estimated € 60. The capacity of the hospital at the end of the pilot face is to be 2,000 patients per month.The applicant is by origin an Afghan medical doctor who is licensed in the Netherlands as a district nurse. He runs a health care company and concerns himself mostly with setting up the management of the hospital, training programmes for medical personnel and telemedicine facilities. The major part of training and telemedicine will be done by the Narayana Health Centre in Bangalore and specialists in Maastricht and Amsterdam pledged their support to contribute to this end as well.

Beef and dairy products are an important part of the Afghan diet. Local cattle is high in number but low on production. Cattle holders seek ways to improve their stock as they cannot meet local demand. Importing cattle is very challenging in a country like Afghanistan. NGOs and donor organisations set up small artificial insemination (AI) projects. This helped to some extend to improve livestock, but as funding is limited, it is not sustainable. The applicant has successfully set up AI businesses in forty countries, including developing markets. With an Afghan-Dutch national they elaborated a plan to approach the vast but challenging Afghan market. They contacted the local partner who runs a seed business and has many cattle owners as customer. Together with a cattle trading company they agreed on a business model. The core business is to provide imported semen to local cows and to breed a stock of improved Afghan bulls for local semen production. Insemination will be done by 50 employed and 100 free-lance inseminators. As there are virtually no veterinary services available, the joint venture will provide a comprehensive package including medication, improved feed and comfort products. Although there are some big cattle owners in Afghanistan, the main group of potential customers are small cattle holders. The majority of these small-owners are women who are culturally not allowed to work outdoors and selling milk is often their only source of cash income. They cannot be approached by male inseminators and therefore the joint venture will train at least 75 female inseminators. The joint venture aims to inseminate 0.5% of the total number of cows in Afghanistan in the first three years.

Ce projet multi-pays (Niger, Sénégal, Madagascar, République Centrafricaine) a pour objectif d'améliorer la prise en charge de la malnutrition aiguëmodérée en agissant sur les infections intestinales et en explorant les interactions entre malnutrition, immunitéet modification du microbiome intestinal (études clinique et biologique).

While there are many medical laboratories in Burundi, the quality of medical diagnostics in Burundi is negatively affected by frequent breakdowns of equipment, lack of access to advanced equipment and materials and lack of knowledge and experience among laboratory staff.The project will establish a Diagnostic Solutions Centre that will be able to provide: backup and advanced tests, services of installation-repair-maintenance combined with training of staff, rental of equipment and sales plus training packages for equipment. The clients for these tailored services will be the existing health structures such as hospitals, health centres, clinics and medical laboratories. The centre will be located in Bujumbura and will provide its services to the health structures in the city and will also organise a system of (refrigerated) collection of samples from health structures in the country. The partners Ibis-Pharma from Belgium and Socophar s.u.r.l. will enter into a joint venture. The project is expected to upgrade the diagnostics and so contribute to improved health care in Burundi. Since most medical equipment in Burundi is obtained by direct imports and donations, the after-sales service and staff training is usually poor and/or costly. The centre aims to fill this gap.

Ce projet a pour objectif de contribueràla réduction de la mortalitéet de la morbiditématernelle, néonatale et infanto-juvénile, grâceàla mise enœuvre d'un paquet d'interventionsàhaut impact en faveur de la mère, du nouveau néet de l'enfant dans le cadre de la continuitédes soins (7 pays dont le Niger).

The applicant has investigated the technology for harvesting anti-oxidants from olive mill waste water for some time. The anti-oxidants from olive mill waste water have a very high quality and are used in food, medicines and cosmetics as a health promoting ingredient. The world demand for these products is increasing. In contacts with the local partner the idea came up to implement the technology in the Palestinian Territories. This appeared a feasible idea so the plans were developed to start a project in the region. The project will be situated in Ramallah region. The applicant is Sana Pharmaceutical Research Company from Amman, Jordan and the local partner is Jerusalem Pharmaceuticals Company from Al Bireh, Ramallah. The partners will establish a joint venture company to implement the project. The project is an initiative to utilise an opportunity for producing a valuable product from waste and has an interesting business case.

To contribute to increase utilization of Maternal, Neonatal and Child Health (MNCH) in Zimbabwe. The action seeks to improve the quality of MNCH services in Zimbabwe by increasing accountability for their provision. The aim is to increase understanding and capacity amongst communities and local leaders for MNCH service provider accountability, to strengthen community and service user empowerment to demand quality MNCH services, to ensure the presence of well-functioning accountability mechanisms

De haalbaarheidsstudie betreft een installatie voor de verwerking van stedelijk afval in de regio Dakar waarbij gebruik gemaakt wordt van een nieuwe techniek. De beoogde verwerkingsinstallatie is gebaseerd op scheiding van het afval met de innovatieve OREX-pers ontwikkeld door het Nederlandse bedrijf DB Technologies. Wereldwijd is dit een nieuw concept waarmee onder zeer hoge druk het afval  gescheiden wordt in een droge fractie en een natte, organische fractie. De droge fractie kan uitgesorteerd worden op plastics, papier, hout, metalen, etc. De natte fractie levert na vergisting biogas en compost op.Momenteel wordt het afval in  Dakar vrijwel volledig ongecontroleerd gestort op de regionale stortplaats die allang gesloten had moeten zijn. Het grote aandeel van organisch materiaal in het huishoudelijk afval vertegenwoordigt een hoge waarde aan (duurzame) energie die nu niet benut wordt.  De beperkte kosten van het nieuwe concept in vergelijking met alternatieve verwerkingsmethoden als verbranden, biedt een oplossing voor het probleem van Dakar.  Daarbij kan de regio Grande Dakar model staan voor de afvalproblematiek waarmee veel Afrikaanse metropoolsteden worstelen. De nieuwe techniek van DB Technologies is op een aantal plaatsen al in de praktijk bewezen maar tot nu toe nog niet in een ontwikkelingsland. Dat wil zeggen in situaties met een duidelijk andere samenstelling van het stedelijk/huishoudelijk afval, lage concurrerende verwerkingskosten van ongecontroleerd storten en met nog grotendeels te ontwikkelen afzetmarkten voor materialen en energie uit afval.De studie moet de financiële haalbaarheid aantonen van een eerste verwerkingsinstallatie voor 50.000 ton afval per jaar. Ter vergelijking bedraagt het huidige jaarlijkse afvalaanbod op de regionale stortplaats circa 600.000 ton. Na gebleken haalbaarheid kan in de toekomst gedacht worden aan een modulaire opschaling van de benodigde verwerkingscapaciteit of installaties op meerdere locaties in de regio wat mogelijk logistieke voordelen oplevert.Alvorens de businesscase kan worden opgesteld zijn een aantal deelstudies nodig. Ten eerste moet een kwantitatieve en kwalitatieve analyse van de samenstelling van het huidige afvalaanbod op de regionale stortplaats uitgevoerd worden. Ten tweede moet onderzocht worden welke afzetmarkten er bestaan voor materialen en energie uit de installatie zowel wat betreft huidige omvang van deze afzetmarkten, de gewenste kwaliteiten en potentiële opbrengstprijzen. Voor het biogas is de vraag welke route technisch en financieel het meest aantrekkelijk is zoals omzetting in een wkk naar elektriciteit, rechtstreekse afzet als stookgas in een industrieel proces, etc. Kwantitatief is compost het belangrijkste product en onderzoek naar de afzetmogelijkheden is dan ook van groot belang.  De compostmarkt lijkt daarbij nog nauwelijks ontwikkeld in Senegal. Met inzicht in het te verwerken afval en de gewenste productspecificaties van de outputstromen kan de technische lay-out van de installatie bepaald worden en zijn de materiaal- en energiebalansen van het proces bekend. Mede op basis van de berekende investerings- en exploitatiekosten wordt de businesscase geformuleerd in nauw overleg met Cadak-Car. Dit is de regionale overheidsorganisatie die verantwoordelijk is voor de inzameling en verwerking van het stedelijk afval in de regio en uiteindelijk beslist over een go/no go voor de realisatie van de installatie..De deelstudies worden uitgevoerd door LeapFrog Waste Management met waar nodig ondersteuning doorpartijen in Senegal zoals locale experts, onderwijsinstellingen, recyclingbedrijven en landbouworganisaties. DB Technologies is verantwoordelijk voor het technisch ontwerp van de installatie, de materiaal- en energiebalansen en de ramingen van investerings- en exploitatiekosten. LeapFrog Waste Management  is verantwoordelijk voor het opstellen van de businesscase en doet dit in nauw overleg met Cadak-Car en DB Technologies

Design 180 wil samen met en op initiatief van San Giorgio een plan voor een dergelijk plastic recyclingsysteem en productiefaciliteit opzetten. Deze faciliteit zal allerlei soorten plastic kunnen recyclen en een uitgebreide range van plastic producten maken; nieuwe grondstoffen én eindproducten. Het systeem zal ook een ophaalsysteem voor afvalplastic omvatten.San Giorgio wil investeren in dit systeem. Design 180 wil aantonen dat het ook echt mogelijk is een dergelijk systeem op te zetten met hardware die Design 180 levert en installeert.

To strengthen experts of the Chinese government and non-government organisations in the Guangdong area in their capabilities to develop, implement and enforce legislation on waste and resource management, especially in the new concept of circular economy
Feasibility study Pilot Plant Urban Waste Management

A Seminar Waste water treatment at May 2015 in Kosovo as a starting point of a program for vocation education in the field of waste water treatment. This seminar of a week is aimed to introduce waste water issues to persons concerned from Universities, Industry and central and local Authorities. Besides an introduction to the effects of waste water on the quality of surface water and the technological possibilities to reduce the discharge of waste water, also the need for education and the waste water program will be discussed during the workshop/course. During the seminar agreement on the coordination and counseling of the waste water program in Kosovo will be aimed at. In this way it will be guaranteed that the needs of future employers for professional employees are taken into account.
Goal of this project is to explore business opportunities for Dutch companies in Bolivia's solid waste management sector.
Study for an incinerator for specific (infectious)hospital waste of King Hussein Cancer Centre in Amman.

Goal of this project is to explore business opportunities for Dutch companies in Bolivia’s solid waste management sector.These goals are reflected in four specific objectives:1.		Carry out a preliminary evaluation of the existing (technical) systems for waste management in the cities of La Paz (1,8 million), Cochabamba (0,8 million) and Santa Cruz (1,6 million) and identify existing needs that could be covered by Dutch products and services2.		Identify Bolivian public and/or private enterprises in waste management with an interest in doing business with Dutch counterparts (preferably) on a commercial basis.3.		Identify Dutch suppliers of products and/or services in waste management relevant in the Bolivian context, with an interest in doing business in Bolivia and in participating in a possible trade mission4.		Lay the groundwork for a Dutch Trade Mission to Bolivia in Waste Management.

Capacity building on site conditioning, closure and monitoring of a selected number of landfills in Georgia during a one year period.Additionally to the trainings, a study visit of governmental employees to the Netherlands will take place in order to achieve a better understanding of the techniques and methods required.
The overall objective is to contribute to the establishment of a suitable and sustainable hazardous waste disposal centre in Swaqa landfill.

•	To present the Netherlands as a potential partner in waste management and biomass in Bolivia;•	To organize a first encounter between the Dutch and Bolivian public and private sectors in waste and biomass, with a means to explore opportunities for business and cooperation;•	To further investigate, develop and test a future program of private sector development in waste and biomass in Bolivia through private sector cooperation and business between Bolivia and the Netherlands;•	To underpin this program by selecting a limited but adequate set of public sector cooperation projects.

To further explore the key opportunities and challenges for cooperation, investments and trade in the Life Science and Health sector – as identified in a market study- with the relevant stakeholder from Kenya  and The Netherlands.

To explore the possibilities to develop the waste sector in Myanmar and capacitate the government with Dutch expertise, and hence providing business opportunities for Dutch companies interested to enter the market and work with a capacitated government as counterpart.
To further explore the possibilities to develop the waste sector in Tanzania with Dutch expertise.

An overall upgrade of the waste management system in Dar es Salaam is needed. First steps include upgrading the Pugu landfill and the waste collection system (including waste transfer stations). Important prerequisites for successful investments in the waste management infrastructure are a suitable institutional setting (a waste management authority), a sustainable fee system and a waste management plan.Within this project it will be explored if and how these prerequisites can be met: The purpose is to unite all stakeholders in Tanzania in a coalition to address the waste management system in Dar es salaam and design and agree upon a roadmap for the further implementation strategy. If the outcome of the project is positive, the implementation of the roadmap will be supported though feasibility studies under Develop 2 Build as well as further government capacity building though PSD apps. The actual infrastructure investments could fit with the DRIVE instruments that enables concessional finance for public infrastructure.

Assisting South African at two levels: Provinces and National Governments to prepare for engagement and partnerships with industry to liberate recyclable/usable material from the municipal sector and thus provide essential feedstock for a waste economy (supply side focus).
The identification of biobased valorisation of organic residues in Western Cape and tentatively for other provinces in South Africa.

- To assess the  readiness and willingness of MOH and some counties to fast track community based primary health care with the support of private sector and public private partnerships (PPPs) particularly.- To identify the specific needs to support the stewardship in the public sector to facilitate the fast tracking of those efforts and PPPs.

The overall ob jective of the action is to contribute towards MDG6 and MDG 5 byenhancing the sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) of  adolescents aged between 10-14 years and Young People aged 15-24 years, through improved access to quality SRHR information and services in Zimbabwe, by 2016

Establishing laboratory facilities at the University of Mitrovica equipped to train students in (waste) water analyses and testsregarding the operation of waste water treatment plants including manuals and test programs. These facilities are essential to develop and implement a curriculum waste water treatment at the University of Mitrovica Kosovo.

This project will take the first steps in supporting early dairy development in Shan State in Myanmar. This support is taking place in the framework of the cooperation between The Netherlands and Myanmar in the field of food security. It was requested for by the Minister of Livestock and Fisheries in Myanmar.The objectives of this project are:(1) relationship building and set up facilitation of first movers and training of farmer groups;(2) mobilisation and listing Dutch private sector interests;(3) development of a 'proof of concept': which approach can contribute to an inclusive sector transformation of dairy in Shan State.The project will be carried out in close interaction and cooperation with different local and Dutch partners, facilitated by Solidaridad. This collaborative process must also lead to partnerships and intentions for next steps to develop the dairy sector in SShanShan State in Myanmar in the second half of 2016 and further on.

Theoverall objective of the action is to enable young people in Zimbabwe to make informed and responsible choices about their Sexual and Reproductive  Health to reduce HIV transmission as well as the effects of HIV and AIDS
The Overall objective is to contribute to the combat of the diseases associated with HIV and AIDS pandemic and to improve access to SRHR information and services to young people in Zimbabwe.

The overall objective of the action is reducing young people's risk of teenage pregnancy and contracting HIV and AIDSthrough facilitating young people's (YP's) access to and uptake of Sexual and Reproductive Health ( SRH)  and Prevention of Mother to Child Transmission of HIV (PMTC) servises
The overall project purpose is the improvement and integration of rural health service systems in Colombia, by means of capacity building of national and local policy makers and Colombian scientists.

The purpose of this capacity building project is to establish a locally relevant and easily accessible knowledge base by training farmers in growing different varieties of vegetables, in order to increase the food supply and food security in Cuba. The project partners will set-up a demonstration centre and 2 (small) training centres at vegetable farms for developing the horticultural sector in Cuba – thereby providing a platform to facilitate first steps of Dutch companies starting their activities in Cuba -, as well as repairing and/or constructing low-tech greenhouses. Lastly, the introduction and validation of new vegetable varieties (seeds) in Cuba is key to the project (tomato, pepper, lettuce and possibly melon).

The project purposes are to:•	Identify strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats of the waste water sector in Thailand, both in Bangkok metropolitan area as well as in selected upcountry locations to stimulate Dutch investment and presence of Dutch companies in this sector•	Provide Dutch companies with increased knowledge on the Thai waste water sector and to identify concrete business opportunities for them

The goal of the project is to develop a broadly endorsed and approved, ‘gold standard’, benchmarking and due diligence system for recycling and valorization performance in Colombia, which establishes clearly the performance of both informal and formal recycling in Colombian cities, and the contribution of recycling results to good waste management in Colombia.The project is carried out by Waste. The project  is seeking to design, develop and field-test this benchmarking system, in partnership with Jewel (former NMPO), a solid waste data management and benchmarking firm based in Wageningen, and CEMPRE  (Compromiso EMPresarial para el REciclaje), which represents institutional co-operation between informal recyclers and large consumers goods companies. The project will contribute to the stability of the modernization process, by creating broad stakeholder agreement about what is proof  and what is evidence about recycling and valorisation effectiveness.Carrying out a G2G cooperation with Colombia under TF as well as as a B2B cooperation under PIB. Working for a better position for waste pickers has important development effects as well is a basic condition for investments of Dutch companies in this field (especially recylcing).
To contribute to the reduction of HIV incidence and improvement of Sexual and Reproductive Health (SRH) amongst Youth People in Zimbabwe (MDG 5 and 6).

The proposed action seeks to enlarge the civic space for CSOs and young people to be active citizens participating in public social development and policy processes to enhance a more equitable, open and democratic society in Zimbabwe.
The overall objective of the proposed action is to: Contribute to increased access and uptake of quality MNCH services in Matabeleland North and Matabeleland South.
Captivating and Selling  the Positive Values of Colombian Food and its Related Culture

The purpose of the project is an institutional strengthening of the Ethiopian animal disease control and veterinary services through:- Support in the development of surveillance programs of the Ministry of Agriculture: understanding of risk assessment, epidemiology and vaccination programs including regulations and responsibilities of the different stakeholders.- Improvement of the laboratory diagnostic capacity of NAHDIC.- Support of the disease monitoring and prevention in the field, disease diagnosis, disease prevention (via knowledge transfer  of  vaccination programs, hygiene and other management factors) and sampling by the regional laboratories and practitioners.

The PASS project brings together public private and NGO sectors to provide clear roles and partnerships for delivering sanitation and hygiene services effective ways of funding them and strenghtened capacity. Expected results include:Initiation: a.o. Partnership agreement baseline and CSR by September 2014Compound Sanitation: 45,000 people with access to a new or upgraded toilet, reflecting strenghtened supply and demand for compound sanitation in GWMA by December 2017GWMA revenue: Strenghtened capacity of GWMA to collect revenue for financing FSM and school sanitation by September 2016School sanitaton and hygiene: 1,600,000 school children with improved hygiene knowledge nationally and 7,700 children in GWMA with access to improved school WASH facilities by December 2017Waste management: 40,000 people in GWMA with better FSM services by December 2017FInalisation: project completed learning disseminated and finalisation requirements met by March 2018.

The business case is built on two pillars: the WASH model on one hand with controlled sourcing of liquid waste by establishing a certified Toilet Services Network (TSN), combined with controlled solid waste collection in a Solid Waste collection Network (SWN). The second pillar is the Waste Re-use model with waste treatment and production and sale of the end-products bio-fertilizer to farmers and delivery of green electricity to the grid. The project will benefit approximately 125,000 people by the end of 2016 which corresponds to approximately 50% of the total population in the target municipality.

The project goals is to support and increase the interest of stakeholders in the public private sector in the commerialization of sustainable reuse and recycling of wastes in order to reduce waste transport costs support the lifetime of landfills and reduce environmental impacts. The project proposes 3 main components:1. a co composting facility in Techiman which will annually transform 6,000 m3 of faecal sludge from public toilets and houdeholds and 300 tons of organic urban solid wastes (including e.g. market waste) into 200 tons of safe (pelletized) compost under the brand name Fortifer. Drying beds are used fo primary treatment of the faecal sludge prior to co composting.2. A briquette plant in Afienya (Dangme West) to convert 3,300 tons per year of organic urban solid wast into 1,000 tons per year low cost fuel briquettes for use by business institutions and households3. The production of African cat fish and or fish feed in well treated waste water in Kumasi to create enough revenue to cover the operational and maintenance costs of the treatment ponds. In concept all interventions will be supported by capacity building activities of public and private sectors. The project creates direct employment for 200 people and more in the product distribution and retail chain primarily women.

The project aims at significantly improving the living conditions of 300,000 people in and environment of the Municipal Assemblies of Nsawam-Aodoagyiri, GA Central and GA West. This by treating approximately 50% of the estimated annual faecal sludge generation in these MAs. The project installs six 30-seater sanitation blocks (plus 4 after the project duration) and 3 Waste Water Treatment Plants (WWTP) at the project locations. At the WWTP's, production facilities for biogas, fertilizer will also be established.

The project distinguishes four key problems to be tackled that would much contribute to an effective solid waste management structure:i) Limited SWM and waste recycling capacity.ii) Limited capacity of the local government (TMA) to provide adequate SWM services.iii) High unemployment and unsanitary conditions in targeted communities.iv) Shortage of electricity supply.The ultimate objective of the project is to reverse this downward spiral and generate electricity, improve SWM capacities (knowledge and know-how) and customer services and provide employment in the solid waste sector.The intervention strategy is to realise a sustainable Waste to Energy Plant that includes a Pre-Treatment and Materials Recovery Facility, Plastics Buy-Back Centres and Customer Care. The activities will deliver new jobs and training opportunities. Over eight thousand households will receive bags to sort out plastic waste at the household source and receive additional income from sales. Hygiene improvement will be accompanied by better working conditions of primarily waste pickers and by providing residents training in occupational health and safety and registration with National Health Insurance (including free vaccinations).

Currently, the Accra Metropolitan Area inhabits more than 1 million citizens and is the most densely populated administrative area in Ghana. The Accra Metropolitan Assembly (AMA) and adjacent municipalities presently dispose most of their faecal sludge directly and untreated into the sea at the Korle Gonno Lagoon and at the so-called Lavender Hill. The only wastewater treatment plant in the Metropolis (Mudor plant), north of the lagoon, is undergoing rehabilitation but is not suitable for bulk (truck) delivery of faecal sludges and only treats 15% of AMA sewage, mostly servicing the central business area and nearby areas. Other areas are served by on-site septic tanks and pit latrines, however a large proportion of the population of Accra still relies on non-sewage public toilets, on-site sanitation facilities or on open defecation.The present situation of very limited wastewater/sludge treatment leaves many areas in the Metropolis and surrounding areas ill-served with serious environmental effects on land and water quality, caused by high concentrations of biochemical contaminants. Accompanied by harsh living and working conditions under very poor hygienic circumstances, especially with the poor, this causes many health problems with regular outbreaks of cholera and other diseases.The Bola Bondeh project builds on the challenges in faecal sludge collection and disposal reducing the negative environmental impact and health hazards of dumping untreated liquid waste into the sea and other water bodies. Close to Lavender Hill, a wastewater treatment facility was installed in 2012 with a daily treatment capacity of 600 m3 sludge and has been in operation since. The Danish Development Cooperation Directorate DANIDA has issued approval to financially support the expansion of the facility to 800 m3 and build another on a nearby site for 800 m3 sludge treatment. For a final approval the conditions to be met are in a progressive stage.The scope of the underlying project lies with the treatment and re-use of excreta and environmentally sound disposal. Based on a supply chain and nutrient recycling approach the objectives of the project are to: Strongly reduce discharge of untreated wastewater in surface waters or sea around the Lavender Hill location Improve hygienic sanitation situation at community and household level in Jamestown Introduce simple and robust techniques for treatment of wastewater, urine and organic matter Develop private businesses in composting Use of compost as part of good agricultural practices (GAP) in (peri-urban) agriculture.
Le projet de l’association ALIMA, d’un montant total de 650 000 euros, viseàréduire la malnutrition et ses conséquences pour les enfants de moins de cinq ans.

Ce projet s'inscrit dans le cadre du plan d'action du programme sécuritééconomique de l'organisation au Nigeria pour l'année 2017 (environ 32 millions d'euros). Les fonds obtenus dans le cadre de cette deuxième tranche devraient permettre au CICR l'achat, le transport et le stockage de denrées alimentaires pour 39 300 personnes pour un mois dans les régions les plus touchées par la crise alimentaire, particulièrement dans les districts les plus isolés oùseul le CICR est présent.
Ce projet vise la création d'un centre d'accueil pour les personnes handicapées.
Ce projet vise le renforcement de capacités et accompagnement aux structures d’hygiène et d’assainissement.

L’objectif du projet est de doter la commune d’un poste de santémoderne afin d’améliorer les conditions de santédes populations et d’hébergement du personnel soignant de santé. Le projet comprend la construction d'un dispensaire, d'une maternitéet d'un logement pour l'Infirmier Chef de Poste (ICP).

L'objectif du projet est d'améliorer la couverture sanitaire dans la Commune d'Enampore par la construction d'une Case de santépermettant de polariser près de 8.000 villageois. Le projet permettra, outre la construction de la case de santé, de former le personnel (agent de santécommunautaire et matrone) et de l'accompagner par des praticiens expérimentés dans le cadre de partenariats avec des organismes de formation et des médecins.

Le projet doit contribueràaméliorer les conditions de vie de la population de Koulinto en créant les conditions d’une prise en charge rapide et de qualitédes problèmes de santédes populations de Koulinto, en particulier ceux des femmes et des enfants.Le projet présentévise ainsiàdoter la Commune de Koulinto d’un poste de santéqui comprendra : un dispensaire, une maternité, un logement pour l’ICP et un puits. La Case de santéserait recyclée en logement pour la sage-femme.

Le projet viseàcontribueràl’amélioration de la couverture sanitaire dans la Commune de Kolda par la construction et l’équipement d’un Poste de santéen quartier Zone Lycée.Le Poste de santésera bâti sur une parcelle située dans les hauteurs du quartier Zone Lycée qui est en cours de viabilisation (eau etélectricité) par la Commune. Le projet sera composéde la construction et de l’équipement d’un dispensaire, d’une maternitéet d’un logement qui hébergeraàla fois l’ICP et la sage-femme.

Ce projet viseàaméliorer la santéet le bien etre des populations de Kedougou. La construction de ce poste de santédans le quartier de Ndiormi permetàla fois l'accès aux services de santépour les 8815 habitants du quartier mais aussi un désengorgement des structures deja existantes dans la ville. Y seront présents un service de santématernelle et néonatale, un service de santéinfantile, un service de santéprimaire et curative et des logements pour la sage-femme et l'infirmier.

Ce projet a pour objectif d'offrir l'accès aux services de santéaux habitants du village de Bokissaboudou et des villages alentours par la construction et l'équipement d’une case de santéaméliorée afin d'assurer une meilleure prise en charge des populations locales et de permettre aux femmes d'accoucher dans des conditions décentes ainsi que l'accompagnementàla mise en place d'un comitéde santéen charge de la gestion des ouvrages sanitaires

Le projet porte sur la construction et l’équipement d’une case de santécomposée d’un bureau de consultation, d’un dépôt pharmaceutique, d’une salle de soins, d’un bloc sanitaire et d’une clôture de 120 mètres linéaires. Il s’agira aussi, en lien avec les autorités sanitaires  d’appuyer la mise en place et la formation d’un comitéde santépour la gestion et le fonctionnement de la case

Améliorer l'accès et la qualitédes services de santéaux 5.300 habitants du village de Thialy et des villages alentours.Le projet concerne la rénovation du poste de santédu village de Thialy et la création d’une nouvelle maternité, d’un logement pour le personnel soignant, des aménagements extérieurs, d’un abri pour les accompagnants et la réhabilitation du mur de clôture. Il est prévu aussi de renforcer l’équipement enéquipant la maternitéavec du matériel médical et du mobilier.Parallèlementàla réalisation de l’infrastructure, un appui technique sera apportéau comitéde santéqui est l’instance de gestion stratégique de l’établissement. Cet appui viseàaméliorer la capacitéde gestion du comitéetàrenforcer son dynamisme organisationnel.

Le projet vise la mise en place d'une case santéaméliorée pour le village de Wassacode afin de délivrer une médecine de proximité(via l'agent de santécommunautaire et les permanences régulières de l’infirmier du poste de santéde Sinthiou Garba) aux habitants du village ainsi qu'àceux venant des villages situés plusàl’intérieur des terres dans le Diéry. Wassacode comme d’autres villages de cette zone font faceàun enclavement marquédurant la période d’hivernage. Les populations habitants de cette partie du Diéry rencontrent d’importantes difficultés pour accéder au premier poste de santésituéàSinthiou Garba.Le projet consisteàréaliser une infrastructure sanitaire comprenant une pharmacie, une salle de soin hommes et femmes, un bureau infirmier et une salle d’accouchements. Il s’agira de construire les locaux, de leséquiper, de constituer le 1er lot de fournitures et consommables avec appui, suivi et contrôle et de mettre en place d'un organe de gestion (comitéde santé) favorisant la participation communautaire dans le dispositif, sous la supervision des autorités médicales compétentes.

The overall objective of the action is to improve access to basic services to all Zimbabweans, thus supporting Zimbabwe to achieve health MDGs 1c, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and 8eThe Purposes of the action are:To improve maternal, newborn and child health by strengthening health systems and scaling up the implementation of high impact maternal, neonatal and child health (MNCH) interventions through support to the health sector.

Cette collectivitélocale est peuplée de 13 626 habitants avec une proportion de jeunes et de femmes dont la moitiéest enâge de procréation. Cette dernière tranche est directement concernée par le projet qui compte leur octroyer des prestations sanitaires adéquates : aujourd’hui ces populations se rendent soit au Centre Hospitalier Régional (CHR) de Ndioum situéà45Km ou au centre de santéde Pétédistant de 55Km pour des consultations. Ce qui occasionne un long déplacement dans des conditions de transport toujours difficiles.Le projet global concerne la réalisation d’unétablissement sanitaire de type centre de santédont la création aétéapprouvée par le Ministère de la Santéet de l’Action sociale au mois d’août 2016. Cette infrastructure de référence viendra suppléer le dispensaire actuel d’AéréLao qui est vétuste et hors normes. Spécifiquement, ce projet vise :•Le renforcement des structures sanitaires adaptées dans la localité,•L’adéquation de l’offre de santéaux besoins des populations,•Le relèvement du plateau technique notamment en gynécologie-obstétrique pour l’accouchement des femmes,•Le renforcement des capacités d’interventions de la structure sanitaire  notamment en santéde la reproduction et pédiatrique afin de réduire la mortalitéinfantile et maternelle,•L’élargissement de l’offre des soins de santédans le district sanitaire.

Ce projet consiste en une aide alimentaireàla prise en charge de la malnutrition aiguëmodérée chez les enfants de 6à59 mois, issus de la population locale dans la bande sahélienne du Tchad.

Ce projet consiste en une aide alimentaireàla prise en charge de la malnutrition aiguëmodérée chez les enfants de 6à59 mois, issus de la population locale dans la bande sahélienne du Tchad. Il est mis enœuvre par le Programme alimentaire Mondiale au Tchad.

Ce projet doit, sur une période de 6 mois, répondre immédiatement aux besoins alimentaires de 4000 ménages les plus affectés par l’insécuritéalimentaire et la malnutrition. Cette contribution permettraégalement de créer ou de réhabiliter les actifs productifs et de renforcer les services de base.Il est mis enœuvre par le Programme Alimentaire Mondial.

Under five-nutrition is still a major problem in Indonesia and one that has not improved much over the last decade. Indonesia is off track to meet MDG1. In fact, Indonesia ranks the fifth in world for the total number of children under five suffering from stunted growth and lags significantly behind other similar middle-income Asian countries in key nutrition indicators. Stunting prevalence among children under five years old (U5) was 37% in 2007 and it had only decreased slightly to 36% by 2010.  The percentage of underweight U5 old Indonesian children has remained stagnant at 18% since 2007.  In addition, maternal anemia is estimated at 44% and more than 11% of Indonesian children are born with low birth weights.  Low birth weight prevalence has actually increased in Indonesia during the 2000s. Therefore, actions are required to address the high rate of stunting in these districts, particularly by targeting the most vulnerable populations including pregnant women, neonates, infants, and young children.In this project Save the Children will contribute to this by building an Infant and Young Child Feeding IYCF programming model to address stunting including increasing demand for nutrition and health services; improving the availability and quality of those services; and improving household nutrition practices.  We will compliment this by working to enhance the enabling environment and the impact of services that do exist.  We will implement all actions through current structures so that good practices can be replicated.  Our targeted, multi-faceted, and intensive approach will allow us to share lessons learned throughout the two target districts and the East Java province in order to seek scale-up of promising actions principally by using public sector health and nutrition funding.  All activities will contribute to achieving the objectives of the overall GAIN BADUTA nutrition project in Indonesia and fit within the overall structure of the broader project.
Reducing HIV /AIDS through healthcare&business enterprise training , for out of school adolescent girls and young women and through delivery of HIV services to people in rural Uganda;

The Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS) is the primary global multilateral agency responding to HIV/AIDS. Its mandate is to provide international coordination, leadership, strategic guidance and advocacy to mobilise global resources for the HIV response.  Funding of $7.5 million under this investment represents Australia's 2015 annual contribution, to support the UNAIDS Strategy 2011-15 and the work of the UNAIDS Regional Support Team for Asia and the Pacific. This investment is guided by a strategic partnership framework.

Funding under this initiative aims to strengthen the evidence base for nutrition policy and programming in the Asia-Pacific region. Funds will support the World Bank to conduct regional and country-level analysis of malnutrition, and to stimulate awareness of and commitment to improved nutrition across the region.  The total value of this initiative is $1.0 million over 1 financial year, 2013-14.

On the 8th August 2014 the World Health Organisation (WHO) announced the Ebola outbreak in West Africa (affecting Sierra Leone, Guinea, Liberia and Nigeria). The outbreak is the largest the world has ever seen and WHO estimates up to 20,000 cases over the next six to nine months without intensified control measures. Following the announcement the WHO formally requested Australian support to assist with the WHO consolidated appeal to respond to the outbreak. Through the WHO Ebola response roadmap which identifies immediate needs and priorities, funding under this investment contributes to Australia's response to the Ebola outbreak and will provide support for human resources and medical expertise, logistics, supplies and equipment and food and water for those in affected regions. The total value of this investment is $12.0 million expensed in the 2014-15 financial year.

The Sports Diplomacy Strategy aims to:•	Connect people and institutions;•	Enhance sport for development;•	Showcase Australian capability; and•	Support innovation and integrity in Sport.3. The ASP provides a practical means to advance key priorities for the region including supporting emerging leaders, youth, women and girls.  It will look to provide funding to support new programs, expand National Sporting Organisations’ geographic focus, trial new approaches, and develop new partnerships.

The International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF) is a global non-government organisation that delivers sexual and reproductive health services.  It works in 172 countries through 152 Member Associations. In 2016 Australia provided AUD $4.6 million as an annual core contribution to support the IPPF’s 2016-2020 Strategic Framework.  The Strategic Framework focuses on promoting and delivering access to sexual and reproductive health and strengthening the legislative and policy environment around these services.

Phase 2 of the Pacific Sports Partnerships program (PSP 2), (2013–17) is a $14 million  competitive grants program that aims to use sport to develop healthier and more inclusive communities in the Pacific. PSP 2 encourages more Pacific islanders, regardless of gender or ability, to be more active, more often by playing sport at a grassroots and community level, and to use sport to achieve positive social development outcomes that contribute to Australia’s aid program.
