Get Up Speak Out alliance (GUSO): This alliance consists of Rutgers, dance4life, Simavi, International Planned Parenthood Federation,STOP AIDS NOW!, CHOICE for Youth and Sexuality, in a partnership with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The GUSO programme addresses the following problem; Young people do not claim their sexual rights and their right to participation because of restrictions at community, societal, institutional and political levels. This hinders their access to comprehensive SRHR education and services that match their needs, and ability to make their own informed SRHR decisions. To address this problem the GUSO programme uses a multicomponent approach in which it links (i) provision of sexuality education and information, (ii) provision of quality, youth-friendly SRH services and (iii) building support for youth SRHR, by addressing socio-cultural and political barriers in terms of practices, norms and policies. CHOICE aims to empower young people to increasingly voice their rights, meaningfully involve young people in all stages of organizations and program, strengthen the capacity of youth-led organizations to become sustainable, and encourage, capacitate and empower youth advocates to advocate for their sexual and reproductive rights at local, national and international level.

Millions of adolescent girls all over the world are facing a limited future because of early marriage (EM), teenage pregnancies and female genital mutilation/cutting (FGM/C). With this project, by changing the attitude of community members and other key persons and informing adolescent girls and boys, adolescents will be empowered to stand up for their sexual reproductive health and rights (SRHR). Through education, (economic) empowerment and meaningful youth participation, supported by the relevant legislation and policies, the project will give adolescents alternatives beyond EM, teenage pregnancies and FGM/C.

Right Here Right Now (RHRN) is a strategic partnership between Rutgers Netherlands, Asian-Pacific Resource and Research Centre of Women (ARROW), CHOICE for Youth and Sexuality, dance4life, Hivos, International Planned Parenthood Federation Africa Region (IPPF AR), Latin American and Caribbean Women’s Health Network (LACWHN) and the Dutch Minister of Foreign Affairs. The partnership addresses the limited protection and respect and the hindered fulfillment of the Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) of young people in 10 countries and one sub-region, in low- and middle-income countries in Africa (Kenya, Senegal, Uganda, Zimbabwe), Asia (Bangladesh, Indonesia, Nepal, Pakistan), and Latin America (Bolivia, Honduras) and the Caribbean, with a focus on: freedom from stigma, discrimination and violence, access to comprehensive youth-friendly services and to comprehensive information regarding young people’s SRHR, and space for young people’s voices and meaningful participation. CHOICE aims to ensure the meaningful participation of young people throughout the RHRN programme at all levels and in all phases. In addition to doing our own advocacy, CHOICE will also encourage, capacitate and empower youth advocates at the national and international level, ensuring that they can create a critical mass to advocate for and voice their SRHR.

This project will reduce under-five mortality by reducing diarrhoea prevalence through improving sanitation coverage and hygiene practices for the entire population of 3 rural Local Government Areas (LGA) in Cross River State, Nigeria. Combining behaviour change through CLTS and hygiene promotion, 702,000 people will benefit from open defecation free environments which will decrease under-five diarrhoea rates by 10% and contribute to reductions in under-five mortality.

Based in Baglung and Myagdi districts in the Western region of Nepal, the project will work with 1500 unpaid family carers of individuals with mental illness. As a result of the project:- medical and counselling facilities for carers will be strengthened- 60 carers mutual support groups will be formed and operational- alternative care and respite arrangements for carers will be set up and working- carers will have access to livelihoods and skills training opportunities- support will be in place to enable child carers to attend school regularly- capacity of the partner organisation in Nepal, local government staff, community volunteers and carers will be strengthened to promote needs of carers and advocate for policy change;

In Chad, 86% of women do not have a skilled health professional assisting them in childbirth, leading to increased risks of disability and death for the mother and newborn in the event of complications. Chad’s poor Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) has shown no signs of improvement since 1990 and is significantly off-track for meeting the MDG5 target. This project will improve maternal health for vulnerable women in north N’Djamena by improving community antenatal awareness, service delivery, advocating for regionally improved birthing practices through the government taskforce, and building the capacity of Chadian midwives through expert training.

Get Up Speak Out alliance (GUSO): This alliance consists of Rutgers, dance4life, Simavi, International Planned Parenthood Federation, aidsfonds, CHOICE for Youth and Sexuality, in a partnership with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The GUSO programme aims at empowering all young people, especially girls and young women, to realise their SRHR in societies that are positive towards young people's sexuality. To address this problem the GUSO programme uses a multicomponent approach in which it links (i) provision of sexuality education and information, (ii) provision of quality, youth-friendly SRH services and (iii) building support for youth SRHR, by addressing socio-cultural and political barriers in terms of practices, norms and policies. dance4life brings expertise on SRHR information and education. Targeting youth in- and out-of schools, d4l - together with the partner organization - engage young people through dance, music, theatre and online platforms and empower them to increase their confidence, to change attitudes and norms and behaviors.

The program Get up, Speak out! (GUSO) raises awareness amongst young people of their sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR), with all the consequences that that entails, and will give them a voice. Get up, Speak out! is a unique and strong concept that will tackle several levels at once. It focuses on strengthening the individual capacity of young people and at the same time GUSO will improve the (availablility of) sexual and reproductive health services and referral system to these services. GUSO is implemented in Kenya, Ethiopia, Ghana, Uganda, Malawi and in Asia in Indonesia and Pakistan. In GUSO young people will be involved at all levels, from the set up of the programme to the decision-making. Parents, care-takers, teachers and community leaders will also be involved. dance4life brings expertise on SRHR information and education. Targeting youth in- and out-of schools, d4l - together with the partner organization - engage young people through dance, music, theatre and online platforms and empower them to increase their confidence, to change attitudes and norms and behaviors.

The program Get up, Speak out! (GUSO) raises awareness amongst young people of their sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR), with all the consequences that that entails, and will give them a voice. Get up, Speak out! is a unique and strong concept that will tackle several levels at once. It focuses on strengthening the individual capacity of young people and at the same time GUSO will improve the (availablility of) sexual and reproductive health services and referral system to these services. GUSO is implemented in Kenya, Ethiopia, Ghana, Uganda, Malawi and in Asia in Indonesia and Pakistan. In GUSO young people will be involved at all levels, from the set up of the programme to the decision-making. Parents, care-takers, teachers and community leaders will also be involved. dance4life brings expertise on SRHR information and education. Targeting youth in- and out-of schools, d4l - together with the partner organization - engage young people through dance, music, theatre and online platforms and empower them to increase their confidence, to change attitudes and norms and behaviors.

Millions of adolescent girls all over the world are facing a limited future because of early marriage (EM), teenage pregnancies and female genital mutilation/cutting (FGM/C). With this project, by changing the attitude of community members and other key persons and informing adolescent girls and boys, adolescents will be empowered to stand up for their sexual reproductive health and rights (SRHR). Through education and economic empowerment, supported by the relevant legislation and policies, the project will give adolescents alternatives beyond EM, teenage pregnancies and FGM/C. The project will be implemented between 2016 and 2020 by Plan Nederland, together with partners Amref, Rutgers, Choice, KIT and the Netherlands’Embassies in the relevant countries. It will be carried out in Ethiopia, Kenya, Zambia, Malawi, Mozambique, Indonesia and Pakistan.

In Indonesia KIT is responsible for conducting research on the root causes of child marriage, female genital mutilation&teenage pregnancies, testing the assumptions of the theory of change, and for measuring effectiveness of strategic interventions on child marriages, female genital mutilation&teenage pregnancies. This means that KIT is responsible for the base and end line studies, the midline and the operational research KIT closely collaborates with local researchers and capacitates local research teams in mixed methods and knowledge management. The research has the aim to test the underlying assumptions of the programme’s theory of change, to measure the effectiveness of the interventions introduced by the programme and to look into the interrelations between child marriage, female genital mutilation and teenage pregnancy and the interventions that address these in Indonesia. The research will contribute to the optimization of the Yes I Do intervention strategies and provide context specific knowledge for advocacy and policy purposes, in order to move towards a situation in which adolescent girls can decide if, when and whom to marry and if, when and with whom to have children, and are protected from female genital mutilation/cutting. Furthermore KIT will lead on the validation and dissemination of research outcomes, and analysing country specific Monitoring and Evaluation data for lessons learned and measuring outcomes and impact of the Yes I do Alliance in Indonesia.

KIT will lead on the validation and dissemination of research outcomes, developing M&E tools, indicators and analysing M&E data for lessons learned and measuring outcomes and overall impact of the Yes I do Alliance. KIT will analyze and disseminate knowledge that has come out of the 7 country specific baseline and end line studies and the midline and operational research. Based on the research and M&E data analysis, KIT will contribute to the learning agenda led by PLAN. KIT is furthermore part of the research alliance of three Child Marriage Alliances in the Netherlands which is assumed to establish a broad‘child marriage related research agenda’which will include research themes and questions, methodology, comparability of research data, etc. Although per alliance the respective theory of change will be leading, indicators will be aligned where this is possible.

This project aims to contribute to socio-economic empowerment through combined approach to leprosy, lymphatic filariasis). Our target groups consist of people affected or at risk of TB, lymphatic filariasis, leprosy and other neglected diseases. We also target family members of the people that have been disabled by any of those diseases. In health service provision we also try to ensure multiplication of our impact and hence target government health care providers, community health workers, and community volunteers. The core of our services is: detection, diagnosis, treatment and awareness and education.  ;

This project benefits community members, especially women, in rural Bangladesh either at risk of contracting leprosy and LF through early detection services or those diagnosed with leprosy and LF, through increased access to quality health services resulting in reduced transmission, morbidity and disability. The project will be participatory, empowering women to detect the early signs of leprosy and LF, teaching self-care practices and strengthening the local health service response

Since 1996 the North Kivu Province has faced war and violence, the harmful effects of which have deeply affected children. Children continue to experience serious violations of their rights, including recruitment into armed forces and militia groups, abductions, massacres, and family separation. According to the 2013 Humanitarian action plan from OCHA DRC, more than 40,000 children are non-accompanied and vulnerable, 2,000 child soldiers have been removed from armed forces and 1.7 million 3-17 year olds are not attending school. CAFOD is partnering with CAJED and Aprofime to restore hope and dignity in the lives of Congolese children and young people with a sustainable protection and early recovery programme.CAJED is one of our strategic partners based in North Kivu, working in area of child protection for more than 15 years. This project, presented by CAJED, is the continuation of the DRC218 project - a three year project that that will train and reintegrate over 2,000 children. Over the two last years the project has already reached 852 vulnerable children in Goma town and Masisi territory.This particular project will bring lasting change to the lives of 500 vulnerable children and young people – former child soldiers. The project will support:- Formal Education reinsertion: Responsible community members and social workers will identify and sensitise vulnerable children out of school to attend school in the next school year;- Vocational training and life skills: Some vulnerable children who are not able to attend formal education are assessed and trained in vocational and life skills. At the end of each six month training cycle, trainees are equipped with start-up kits to open their own workshops with closed supervision and support from CAJED;- Small scale trading: there are some youths who will not like to attend school or vocational trainings. They will be trained in small scale trading, mainly in groups of 4 to 7 members.The project budget is 75,600.00$, equivalent to £45,000.00. CAJED will continue to work with APROFIME, on issues related to girls’ protection. APROFIME is a local NGO specialising in the care of children and young mothers and they have been working with CAJED for over 10 years now.

The security situation in the province of South Kivu is characterized by the several factors:- The inaccessibility of many areas in which focus protection incidents due to lack of physical access (roads in a state somewhat degraded) or  security (presence of armed groups) resulting in the recruitment of ex-combatants adults or former children associated with armed forces and groups.- Problems that remain unresolved and constitute the seeds of new conflicts in particular related to land issues and identity, as well as the presence on Congolese soil of foreign armed groups including the FDLR and FNL.- The chaotic management of natural resource exploitation and greed that they create vis-à-vis neighboring countries.The lack of hope in the future resulting pushes young people to think the solution to search through involvement in armed groups. Those who have been demobilized are still more likely to go back as far as the social reintegration robust mechanisms that can withstand up issues are not reinforced.From January 2011 to February 2012, Caritas Congo were funded in the dioceses of the eastern DR Congo (Uvira, Butembo Beni, Bunia, Kongolo Kalemie and Bukavu) a project of technical capacity and material combinations of ex combatants and members of host communities. This project has established 22 small development structures composed of adult ex-combatants  and  members of host communities. These 22 structures were validated by the unit of execution of the national DDR / antenna of Bukavu. Necessary basic kits were given to these associations, each according to its sector to run and consolidate operations.However, the project ended without appropriate exit strategies for this target and it felt a need to support the integration and clean errors occurred for some associations. This project would therefore compensate for this gap and thereby promote improved financial management, technical and organizational development for these young associations.CAFOD and its partner, Caritas Bukavu, initiated a programme to support the socio economic reinsertion of these former child soldier and ex combatants in South Kivu in April 2013 with co-funding from Caritas Australia. The programme is multisectoral and giving returning youth an accelerated skills training and livelihoods assistance and preventing many from joining rebel groups. During the first year of implementation the project helped the creation of 10 new associations passing from 22 to 32 associations of ex combattants involved in livelihoods activities.The project aims to strengthen the reintegration of ex-combatants who have returned to their communities, but who are faced with problems of survival. Accustomed to living on their meagre pay under the flag and rapine authorised by their leaders, many are left to themselves since they have exhausted their safety net.Caritas Bukavu would respond to these challenges by strengthening the reintegration of ex-combatants into their communities of life by boosting their initiatives supported. The project's goal is to see the ex-combatants live in harmony within their communities through income derived from agriculture, the exploitation of their mills, etc.The project will contribute to the socio-economic integration of 700 ex combatants by consolidating their 32 economic structure's groups through the SILC approach relying on crafts, Income Generating activities and agriculture in Kabare, Kalehe, Idjui and Walungu territories these constituting the Bukavu Diocese.To achieve this goal the project has been sized to 120,000.00 usd including a co funding of 80,000.00 usd from Caritas Australia.

The need to strengthening local capacities in humanitarian response in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) is crucial as local NGOs are usually the first responders in a crisis. DRC has been beset by multiple security crises subjecting civilians to extremely high level of violence and prompting large-scale and frequent population displacements. Moreover, there is adequate civil society space in DRC but humanitarian response have been lead and managed by international organizations. On one hand this is due to the logistical difficulties of the country and on the other hand, local organizations have been labelled as having poor management, systems, corruption, etc. The consequence is that INGOs have, in many instance, undermine existing capacities. Shifting the power Project in Drc aims at strengthening the humanitarian and leadership capacities of 11 local actors and so to be able to play a crucial role within the current humanitarian architecture in DRC. From the capacity self-assessment undertaken with Codevah, the organisation has elaborated a one year capacity strengthening plan with 5 objectives and 14 activities focus on increasing leadership, influence and improve emergency preparedness and response capacity.

Overall objective: Follow-up the migrants who left Yemen because of the war and who are in a situation of vulnerability in Djibouti. The migrants are from various nationalities : Yemenite, Ethiopian, Somali and others.Specific objective:1. Provide an emergency medical care to the migrants in conditions of extreme poverty2. Support the migrants families and the women with a food assistance3. Make the migrants be economically autonomous thanks to the projects of microcreditProfile of beneficiaries: The number of beneficiaries is around 530 (cumulated number) and 210 if we rely to the number of participations to the training courses. This number concerns:- 7 families (male beneficiaries), so to say more or less 49 people, concerning the project of microcredit;- 23 families (female beneficiaries), so to say more or less 161 people, concerning the project of professional training (sewing and hairstyling);- 170 sick people receiving a medical assistance;- 150 families receiving food assistance.The profile of the beneficiary is :1. Being migrant, refugee or displaced in a situation of vulnerability and coming from Yemen.2. Being a mother or a father in a situation of vulnerability.3. Not being able to support him/herself for basic needs.

During November 2016 the northern part of the Dominican Republic was affected by storms resulting in severe flooding and landslides and triggering a large slow-onset emergency in 9 provinces. The damage assessments account for 15 people dead and more than 350,000 people affected, 2,500 homes destroyed, 65,000 homes affected, and damage to more than 90,000 hectares of various crops. The objective of the project is to ensure that 5,008 families, from 5 provinces in 5 dioceses of the northern part of the Dominican Republic receive essential needs in the areas of food security, shelter, health, water, sanitation, livelihoods and are able to strengthen their capacities for reconstruction and advocacy.

This project will contribute to capacity strengthening, as well as economic, political and environmental empowerment of women members of the municipal networks for prevention of violence against women in communities in the municipalities of Alta Verapaz, Guatemala.The focus is on nutritional food security and family income, by improving the value of agricultural production, strengthening economic opportunities, local leadership, better services and social benefits for women leaders in gender, services and decent benefits.The proposal aims to focus on the following aspects:a) Productivityb) Organization, Community Leadership and Advocacy of womenc) Women’s Health and Nutritiond) Marketing:e) Organisational strengthening and technical capabilities of the Social Pastoral team in aspects of human rights, food security, climate change, risk management and gender.A second phase of this project is going to start in March 2017.

The Archdiocese of Los Altos, covering the departments of Quetzaltenango and Totonicapán, is situated in the western highlands of Guatemala and populated mainly by Mayan communities from the K’iche and Mam groups. Levels of poverty in the area are the second highest in the country, with 97% of the population living under the poverty line. The area is primarily rural with just 7% of the population living in urbanised settings. In Totonicapán municipality,  40 % of children are malnourished. . GNP per capita is  US$900 and illiteracy levels are amongst the highest in the country at 67% of the population. People suffer from lack of access to basic health and education services and adequate access to food and housing. Within the indigenous population, about 65% are Catholic, but in a form which includes many elements of Mayan spirituality. In addition, a sector of the population practices Mayan religion, while at the same time participating in the Catholic Church within a context of dialogue, reflection and shared learning.  The parish of Santa Maria Chiquimula has worked to recover and disseminate knowledge of Mayan spirituality, traditions and values as a means towards building a more integrated and inclusive church. Its integrated programme covers 37 communities of the parish, strengthening levels of community organisation and participation, providing increased opportunities for education, employment and income-generation through farming practices and improving the quality of preventive and primary health care.

The purpose of the project is to contribute in reduction of Maternal Mortality, morbidity from unsafe abortion and improve the Sexual Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) situation of women and adolescents in the project areas.This project targets to achieve 150500 MR conducted , 12250 patient managed for Complications of unsafe abortion , 322,550 FP methods distributed during Post MR counseling, 80500 individual received Reproductive Health service at school, community and garments, Institutionalized and sustainable attention at the national level to ensure access to safe abortion and family planning.This will be achieved by ensuring that poor and marginalized women and adolescents have access to unsafe abortion and can access modern Family Planning (FP) methods; Providing comprehensive MR and PAC training to health service providers, Raising Awareness and Creation of Demand on SRHR issues and Supporting changes to the regulatory and/ or policy environments for abortion services.SRHR project will help Bangladesh to achieve MDG 5 by increasing family planning use and reducing maternal mortality in Bangladesh.

El objetivo de esta Organización es combatir las enfermedades animales a nivel mundial, mediante la transparencia, información científica, solidaridad internacional, seguridad alimentaria, promoción de los servicios veterinarios y la sanidad de los alimentos y del bienestar animal.

The Catholic Diocese of Mombasa (CAM) Integrated Food Security Programme (IFSP) will be implemented in Kisauni and Lungalunga Sub counties of Mombasa and Kwale Counties respectively. In Kisauni Sub County, the project will be implemented in six sub locations  namely Junda, Kisauni, Magogoni, Kongowea, Bamburi and Maweni; while in Lungalunga  Sub county  it will be  in seven sub locations ; Vanga, Jego, Sega,  Kiwegu, Kasemeni, Kilimangodo and Mwena. The proposed IFS programme is targeting to reach a total of 1,500 direct beneficiaries (750 males and 750 females) and 6,000  indirect beneficiaries (2250 males and 3750 females).  Each direct beneficiary will reach out to 5 indirect beneficiaries in Kisauni and 3 indirect beneficiaries in Lungalunga.The programme will target the food poor, who are among vulnerable House Holds (HHs) such as People living with and affected by HIV, Orphan and Vulnerable Children (OVC), Child headed HH, Female HH, People with Disabilities (PWD), elderly persons, Drug users, sex workers, HHs that did not cultivate in the last 2 seasons, livestock keepers, agro pastoralist farmers, unskilled youth out of school, youth in school (clubs in school) and terminally ill people.The overall goal of CAM IFSP is to promote food security for 250 and 1500 food poor beneficiaries (households and individual) through improved food security, income levels and health status in Kisauni and Lunga lunga programme areas by March 2018.  This programme seeks to address some factors that contribute to food and income insecurity among the targeted HHs through an integrated approach focusing on livestock and crop production, HIV and AIDs prevention as well as income generating activities. Training in the proposed programme will mainly be done through Community Resource Persons (CRP), Field Agents (FAs) and Community Health Workers (CHWs).A Participatory Community Needs assessment was conducted in, 2013 through CAM and CAFOD partnership to inform the project design.  This was done in order to gather in-depth information on the causes of food insecurity, aimed at identifying and evaluating factors contributing to food insecurity and determining other integrated needs of the communities living within Lunga lunga and Kisauni sub counties. According to the findings, key factors contributing to food insecurity identified were: prolonged drought, erratic rainfall, poor methods of farming, community factors contributing to HIV infection (weddings, seasonal dances) and low household income.This IFS programme will work with individuals and groups within target communities to increase crop and livestock production levels through sustainable agriculture principles and practices as a strategy. Various approaches shall be used to achieve this such as Farmers Field schools (demonstration farms), farmers open days, exchange visits, field based trainings and institutional workshops. On HIV and AIDs, formation of community units, open community HIV sensitization meetings, HIV stakeholders meetings.  In order to improve HHs income levels, training on income generation shall be carried out through field agents.The three year programme will be implemented over a period of 36 months commencing May 2015 to April 2018.  The total planned budget for this project is £210,000 with annual disbursements of £70,000 to the partner to support project activities

CAFOD has partnered with bet365 foundation to scale up stigma reduction responses in its HIV programmes in Uganda.  This follows a pilot that was first tried in Ethiopia, Zambia and Mombasa, Kenya over a period of three years.  The project titled evidence responsive HIV stigma reduction project – Uganda is seeking to promote HIV prevention and treatment services by including stigma reduction in the responses.  The project successfully started in November 2014 and will run over a period of one year to close in October 2015Following successful grant processing and transfer to the partner it was observed that the project budget accrued a surplus of £7,057.48 which mainly resulted from favourable exchange rate gains.  It has been agreed after discussions with the two partners, CAFOD project and funding teams and the donor to use this surplus to produce some additional educational/information materials for the communities.  Initially this need was identified as a key project closure activity but not budgeted for.Over the implementation period therefore, partner staff will progressively capture and document unique stigma and discrimination experiences from respondents and good response practices from other change agents including faith leaders.  The unique stories and practices will then be followed up later in the year with an overall production of educational materials to inform transformation realised in the lives of the primary stakeholders of this project. The materials will be in the form of a ‘light read’ booklet on the best practices of this project and an audio visual documentary covering the role of faith leaders in stigma reduction.  Target audiences of these educational materials will include project beneficiaries, supporters of this work and collaborators as a way of showcasing the project impact on target communities.  It is also anticipated that these materials will promote visibility of this project and contribute to HIV stigma advocacy initiatives by all project stakeholders

This project continues the work of St Francis Community Development Programme (FRACODEP) in contributing to the reduction of HIV transmission and in mitigating the impact of HIV and AIDS among youths, PLHIV and the general community in Seme sub-county in the Archdiocese of Kisumu. Working with the Ministry of Health it aims to:- Reduce HIV incidence through onsite and mobile HIV Testing and Counselling (HTC) services;- Strengthen support systems for people living with HIV and at risk of HIV infection, through support groups, enhanced referral services, sensitisation on HIV avoidance, and hygiene promotion;- Enhance livelihood security through training and support for agricultural income-generating activities;- Strengthen organisational and staff capacity to effectively and efficiently deliver quality programme management and community services.

To reduce the incidence of Ebola outbreak in Liberia and to promote the use of preventive methods in the control of Ebola in Bong County, CAFOD is supporting one of her partners Development and Education Network- Liberia (DEN-L) to implement a project that is focused on sensitization. The strategy employed is to conduct public awareness on Ebola through theatre. The public awareness will provide information on EVD through a forum, open engagement and discussion process that allows the awareness team to perform dramas on the modes of transmission and prevention of the disease.

El proyecto implica la preparación de los centros de atención primaria de salud y la capacitación del personal de salud. Esta opción de preparación y respuesta a desastres tiene una mayor eficacia y es más fácil de coordinar puesto que se realiza a través de la red ya disponible de establecimientos sanitarios. El conocimiento de los agentes de salud será mejorado por lo que puede ser una parte del sistema de alerta precoz y de respuesta de primera línea durante y después de los desastres. En la planificación y ejecución del programa se tendrá en cuenta especialmente al Ministerio de Salud Pública y a las organizaciones no gubernamentales pertinentes en la provincia de Laghman de Afganistán

Beca cogestionada con el Grupo Coimbra de Universidades con el fin de realizar estancias de investigación de 3 meses en Grupo de Investigación de Universidades del Grupo Coimbra. Con este programa se pretende apoyar la formación de investigadores en las regiones de África, América Latina y Paises Vecinos de Europa del Este y Asia Central.En concreto ésta, es una beca otorgada a una investigadora albanesa procedente de la universidad de Tirana, que ha desarrollado su trabajo de investigación en el campo de la ginegología del departamento de ginecología y obstetricia de la facultad de medicina de la UGR.

The purpose of this project is to strengthen the provision of HIV testing and counselling (HTC) services to at-risk groups in urban and rural Lilongwe.Operating within the Malawi Extended National Framework coordinated by the National AIDS Commission, CAFOD’s partner The Lighthouse Trust will focus on:- the provision of HTC to TB suspects and patients at Martin Preuss Centre, STI patients at Bwaila Hospital and inmates at Maula Central Prison;- increasing HTC uptake among pregnant and lactating women, at 25 rural health centres;- continued routine counselling and testing of the general population in all its sites, and development of linkages with the community home based care (CHBC) programs;- tracing and follow-up of infected infants, so as to enhance their linkage to antiretroviral treatment (ART) and related services;- psychosocial support for adolescents;- ongoing support, with the Ministry of Health, to all major counselling and testing sites nationwide.

Working in targeted communities in 5 parishes in Lilongwe Archdiocese, the project aims to: reduce the spread of HIV infection; provide access to treatment for people living with HIV and AIDS; mitigate the health, socio-economic and psychosocial impact of HIV and AIDS on individuals, families and communities, especially women and vulnerable children; and mobilise the community on issues of water, hygiene and sanitation.It will do this through: training young people on HIV awareness and sensitisation and life skills, and providing support through youth clubs and activities; training experts and volunteers on services and support for PLWHA and OVCs; training communities in water and sanitation issues, and facilitating the establishment of water and sanitation committees and support structures; and strengthening the communities’ capacity to implement and manage these programmes.The project will build on existing diocesan programmes and structures, in collaboration with other stakeholders such as government, NGOs, FBOs and donor partners.

The overall aim of this project is to equip a total of 197 volunteers with a sound knowledge in basic nursing, how to organise village savings and loans schemes, and how to provide sensitive and culturally appropriate psychosocial and palliative care, in Malawi. It is anticipated that 1,200 people with chronic illness and people leaving with HIV and AIDS will benefit from this project.  The project will implement the following activities in addressing the critical challenges the communities are encountering:- Village savings and loan schemes (VSL)- Palliative care training- Psychosocial training- Technical support of all structures involved in the implementation of the programme remains a critical component of the programme and this requires a motor vehicle, should resources be made available.

The Archdiocese of Lilongwe is responding to the devastating impact of HIV and AIDS in the rural communities of Malawi in Lilongwe Districts. Accessing HIV testing and Counselling and anti retroviral treatment is a challenge throughout Malawi and in Lilongwe it very difficult especially for pregnant women and the sick who are unable to travel long distances to the available health facilities.The Archdiocese has been working in the communities to provide palliative care and support to families and individuals most affected and living with HIV and AIDS. In addition the available rural  health facilities are under staffed and under resourced forcing most patients to be attended to in the home and in their communities. It is because of the limited number of nurses that has led to community led home based care and support.Fuelling the further spread of the pandemic are a number of challenges inherent within the communities in Malawi, such as:poverty and the hardest hit are women and children who in the end make them selves vulnerable through engaging in sex workSexual cultural and religious practices such as the initiation rituals often associated with coming of age, or upon the death of a spouse and these rituals expose women and girls at most and spread to the bigger community.Stigma and discrimination continues to suppress openness about HIV and AIDS resulting in late treatment care and support as well as defaulting on treatmentThis project aims at equipping a total of 197 volunteers with sound knowledge and skills in basic nursing at village and community level and how to organise the village savings and loans schemes, and how to provide sensitive and culturally appropriate psychosocial support an palliative care. The project anticipates to reach out to over 1,200 people with chronic illness and living with HIV an AIDS will be assisted.

A Zomba Research and Development Department (ZARDD) response to a cholera outbreak in Malawi, Zomba Diocese through provision of knowledge on cholera prevention and management in three Traditional Authorities of Zomba District (Mwambo, Mtumanje and Nkumbira) and  T/As Mposa, Nduwa, Kaugule, Mbiringano, Mkwate, Chiwanga, Mbando, Waiye, Chidothi and Chirambo in Machinga district .Malawi is affected by cholera annually in isolated areas of the country, which is inclusive of Zomba. These cholera cases have been on an increase since November 2014 with over 2000 patients treated and more than 50 dying from the disease. There has been challenges in collecting information on these cases hence an underestimation due to unavailability of standardised surveillance system in the country. More than 30 per cent of the districts in the country are reported to have been affected with Cholera and at this time the epidemic has spread across all the regions of the country.The outbreak could probably have risen due to the lack of safe drinking water and inadequacy of sanitation and hygiene. Management of cholera suspects was observed to be substandard by Health workers at both Diocesan as well as Government Health facilities where patients were admitted. Availability of resources to manage the suspected cases has proved a challenge in both Diocesan and Government facilities. Further to this, there has been slow response at District level in sensitisation of communities and alerting the Health workers on prevention and management of cholera respectively.Cholera is preventable by ensuring access to safe water and appropriate sanitation measures. Death from cholera can be prevented through quick access to standardised treatment regimes in health facilities, something which this project seeks to address in Zomba diocese. The response covers needs in the area of surveillance and response, water and sanitation, infection control, social mobilisation and logistics. Sensitising Health workers in handling cases of cholera and alerting the community on hygiene and sanitation, as well as improving water safety will reduce morbidity and mortality.This will be achieved through;- Training of Village Health Committees (VHC)- Conducting of door to door awareness campaigns- Sensitising food vendors in markets on hygiene; and production of banners and t-shirts, hygiene film shows and dramas.- Provision of High Test Hypochlorite (HTH)- Production and broadcasting of radio programmes.- Training of 20 Clinicians, 26 Nurses, 16 Lab Technicians, 4 Pharmacy Assistants and 4 Environmental Health Officers in Cholera management- Procurement and provision of protective wear and medical utilities i.e. Chlorine,Gloves, Cannulas, Intravenous fluids- Training of 552 support staff HSA’s and patient attendants in Cholera prevention and hygiene

The contribution aims at reducing the risk of an outbreak of the Lumpy Skin Disease, LSD in BiH. All the neighbouring countries are struck by the disease and have implemented preventive methods. The Embassy provides a reserve fund for the State Veterinary Office for a rapid response to an eventual outbreak. This will enable the Veterinary Office to purchase vaccines without delay and start a massive vaccination Campaign.The proposed intervention is a way of securing earlier investments in the Agricultural sector and hinder an economic setback. If the livestock of BiH is infected the economic effects would be devastating.

Cont.Título: (...) de las enfermedades infecciosas de transmisión vertical?. Aunque no hay datos exactos, es conocida la falta de asistencia prenatal en un gran número de mujeres embarazadas de la población Mbya-Guaraní. Esta actitud conlleva, entre otros problemas, la falta de diagnósticos de varias enfermedades infecciosas que afectando a la futura madre, pueden ocasionar problemas al producto de la concepción, como aborto, mortinato, parto prematuro y enfermedad congénita. Algunos casos son detectados en las instituciones sanitarias en el momento del parto, pero muchos quedan sin diagnóstico y tratamiento ya que los partos se realizan en las aldeas y sin control sanitario. Se pretende conocer la presencia y el porcentaje de casos de enfermedades infecciosas de transmisión vertical en la población guaraní y a la luz de los datos obtenidos realizar tratamiento de los casos y educación para la salud en la comunidad, con el objeto de que la población indígena tome conciencia de un problema que le afecta y participe de manera activa y colaborativa con las autoridades sanitarias provinciales en la solución del mismo. El proyecto se plantea como proyecto piloto y se realizará en comunidades definidas junto al Ministerio de Salud Pública de la provincia de Misiones y las autoridades aborígenes responsables de las distintas comunidades. Los datos obtenidos permitirán por un lado, diagnosticar y tratar a los casos encontrados y por otro, analizar los conocimientos y actitudes de la población guaraní frente a este problema y confeccionar conjuntamente herramientas que faciliten las actividades de promoción de la Salud en la comunidad.

Título completo del proyecto: Huerto escolar para contribuir a los derechos de las personas a desarrollarse y crecer en su lugar de nacimiento :: Dar apoyo para la creación y desarrollo de un huerto escolar en una escuela de montaña de secundaria que acoge población de 25 barrios. Entre los objetivos del proyecto se pretende transmitir la cultura del cultivo autóctono para evitar en la medida de lo posible, la emigración de la juventud de la zona, así como asegurar que las personas usuarias de la escuela y sus familias refuercen su nutrición

The project contributes to Myanmar (SE Aisa) annual operation plan 2016/17 – ‘key partners capacity strengthend’The quality and speed of CAFOD’s humanitarian work depends on the strength of its partners. The aim HCD for phase 2 of CAFOD in Myanmar is that to ensure greater impact and the overall purpose is existing partner and new partner organizations in country to respond more effectively and efficiently to any future emergencies in compliance with international humanitarian principles and standards. On the other hand, we aim that partner organisations become able to plan and deliver emergency responses to disasters with minimal external support so as to save lives and reduce suffering.Humanitarian capacity development project (HCD) , Myanmar programme, is a partnership project between CAFOD and 3 Myanmar strategic partners (National Caritas); Dioceses of KMSS Yangon, Diocese of KMSS Pathein and KMSS National Office,  aiming at strengthening its capacity to prepare for and respond to emergencies .The project targets to improve performance in the context of planning, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of humanitarian services.  The process hopes to provide in-depth support through trainings and peer learning to improve organisational effectiveness by considering actions that will strengthen leadership and management, levels of skills and knowledge in international humanitarian standards, Disaster Management, fundraising,  MandE framework and safety and security of partners in emergencies.   These targeted areas of trainings were identified and prioritised in the capacity needs assessment workshop.The trainings will not only benefit the 3 Myanmar strategic partners but also representatives of CAFOD Myanmar staff and representatives of partners and CAFOD staff from South East Asia. The identified training areas will in a profound and sustainable manner, improve effectiveness of partner organisations.

World Bank has applied to Embassy of Sweden for funding of 17 940 000 SEK to carry out the  Building Long-term Sustainability for Integrated Solid Waste Management  in Bosnia and Herzegovina (BIH) during the period 2017-2018.The intervention aims at improving the Solid Waste Management sector in BIH, by 1) carrying out Solid Waste Management (SWM) sector Review to inform recommendations for integrated national approach and future sector dialogue and engagement; 2) implementing selected awareness events to kick start civic engagement and outreach to the general public, 3) delivery of selected workshops/training events targeting priority areas of knowledge gap in the sector and 4) Assessment of 1-3 priority investments and pilots.Overall, the intervention represents “Phase 1” of a long-term sector engagement that focuses on priority activities aimed to support BiH to effectively bridge the transition from the current status of SWM to a more integrated sector in alignment with EU Directives. Subsequent and more mature phases are expected to follow building on Phase 1.The intervention’s total budget is 17 940 000 SEK, divided into two phases, Phase 1 10 760 000SEK, and phase 2 7 180 000SEK. Activities in Phase 2 will be defined only after completion of SWM sector review (project component 1) in 2017 and its recommendations. Proposed activities in Phase 2 and second tranche will be subject to Embassy’s approval in 2017. In addition to that, 460 000 SEK has been planned within the separate component to enable technical advice and monitoring during the project implementation. This makes total contribution’s value 18,4 MSEK.
